title: Welcome back Spidey!
review:
Much has been made of this reboot. Personally I welcomed it because Spider-Man 3 was such an atrocity. Sam Raimi is a great director, but ran out of ideas when it came to final instalment of his trilogy. 5 years have passed and we welcome a new Spider-Man in form of Andrew Garfield. We also welcome Marc Webb (no pun intended) as director. As most reboots go, it is an origin story and we all know the story of Peter Parker and how he became Spider-Man. We all know of the tragedy responsible for making him the superhero we all know he is. Andrew Garfield is a great fit as Spider-Man. Not only is he capable of the physical aspects of the role, he also handles himself emotionally too. He is a taller Spider -Man but that's something you should really overlook, because his performance makes him worthy of donning the red and blue suit. More so than Maguire you ask? Yes, I think so.

First starters the nerdy Peter Parker has now been put to bed and a cooler version has surfaced in the form of Andrew Garfield. Garfield looks a lot like the John Romita Jr version of Peter Parker. Not only that, I believed he was Spider-Man. The Spider-Man wisecracks we all know and love are delivered perfectly by Garfield. On top of that, he looks the part. He just does! The Amazing Spider-Man has a lot of emotion and drama to it. Not saying that the previous movies didn't have any heartfelt moments. But this adaptation seemed more realistic, more believable with it's character interactions. I could feel and understand Peter's pain. His parents leaving him with his Uncle Ben (Martin Sheen) and Aunt May (Sally Field) at such a young age and not knowing why, is primarily the reason why the Peter behaves like such an outcast. No friends, just the family he has left. His Uncle Ben is the father figure but not his real father. And the scenes between the Garfield and Sheen are very good. I was waiting for the 'with great power' speech. But it was delivered differently from how we would normally here it. Sheen is great in this, as is Sally Field as Aunt May. Both really do a wonderful job playing Uncle and Aunt. I'd go as far as to say it was even inspired casting. Both actors have a warm quality to them which makes them utterly believable in their roles. Even when Uncle Ben dies (I didn't cry by the way) you feel it. And credit to Webb for not stylising or glamorising the Uncle Ben death scene. It's a pivotal moment in the film, and I thought it was handled very well.

When Gwen Stacy makes her appearance, Peter is love struck and the two eventually become more than friends. Emma Stone is superb as Stacy and adds more life to the character than Bryce Dallas Howard ever did in Spider-Man 3. Rhys Ifans as Curt Connors aka The Lizard was OK. I saw nothing wonderful or unique about what he did with the part. Just a man who was struggling to come to terms with losing one of his arms. The fact character isn't American like the comics makes even less sense than why Ifans was cast. He was just about passable and I cared little for his character. Dennis Leary fairs a little better as Gwen Stacy's police captain father, but again like Ifans adds no meat to his character. Both actors are no more than passengers in this. Visual effects are great. Spider-Man web swinging through the city almost looks like a person was swinging through the Manhattan skyscrapers. A massive improvement on previous Spider-Man movies, which in comparison to this, look weirdly dated. Battle scenes between The Lizard and Spider-Man are well choreographed and well filmed. No shaky cam, just solid action scenes showing you everything from beginning to end. All three encounters between The Lizard and Spider-Man are the highlights of this film.

However, the Lizard looks awful. The creature design for The Lizard borders on amateurish and Ifans' voice over as The Lizard was absolutely rubbish. Why didn't they make him look and sound more menacing? The Lizard looked as if he had been affected by Joker gas. Even when showing anger, he seemed to have this permanent smile across his face. Scenes of real tension were ruined whenever The Lizard opened his mouth. A growl or a roar would've sufficed. His voice for The Lizard would've been perfect for a Saturday morning kids show. Here, it only annoys and because of that I couldn't take The Lizard seriously as an antagonist. Also this film drags and drags. Stacy eventually becomes aware of Peter's secret. But to see how their relationship develops is dry and tedious. The script on the other hand, does just enough to keep you engaged.

Webb's direction is fine especially during the action set pieces. Whether he'll be like Raimi and be around for the two sequels remains to be seen. It's a 3 out of 5 star movie which makes it worth watching but for me, not a repeat watch in the cinema. Though I recommend you purchase this on Blu-Ray and DVD. It's a must for extras. The villain was poor, the plot is hardly original but great visual effects fight scenes, and good performances from Sheen and Garfield save this from being a two star movie. Doesn't belong in the Superhero Hall of Fame, but it's a good superhero movie.

Good to have you back Spidey!

title: the amazing spiderman
review: i saw the amazing spiderman a week ago and i must say what an excellent reboot im even going to go as far as saying that this film is way better that the sam rami original it has a great cast great special effect and a great diologe between the characters i am excited to see were this trilogy of new spideman movie go i can not wait for the amazing spiderman 2 coming out may 2 2014 it will be awesome this movie is a great addition to the spiderman world and eny one who is a fan of the spiderman go do your self a favor and go see this movie. now onto the 3d it was awesome as well not the best 3d but still pretty sweet10/10

title: Definitely the more amazing Spiderman
review:
Before the movie was even released at the cinema, it was seen as a huge risk to even reboot Spiderman after the relatively successful Trilogy prior to The Amazing Spiderman. That said it, seems to have been a risk to be thankful of.

The Amazing Spiderman begins with a brief overview of Peter Parker's background and his parents. Setting the scene for Peter as a person and his beliefs. This can be expanded to really what sets this film apart from Raimi's Spiderman, in that the character development is in my opinion a lot more in-depth and intriguing with the main characters, than in Raimi's. You get to see Peter Parker grow into Spiderman once he acquires his abilities and for example, you get to see Dr Connors reasoning for doing the experiments he is doing with genetics. You got to see Peter Parkers detective skills, intelligence, and inner wars with his own beliefs all build up to who he wanted to be as Spiderman. Garfield, Stone and Ifans gave awesome performances, such that you wished the director to add on a few extra minutes onto some of the emotional scenes and tone down some of the action scenes.

I feel the action is very levelled. There are moments where you feel it almost goes over the top, and moments where you yearn for there to be more than what is actually given. However, they fitted into the film well and were also settings for some of the more humorous moments, something else this film produced fairly often with ease. I would say that some of the sequences were slightly effected when watching it in 3D as I seemed to find it got blurry.

Overall I believe The Amazing Spiderman beats Raimi's Spiderman, and lays solid ground work for future films. It built Spiderman up and looked at what it takes for Peter Parker to balance being a superhero and being human, rather than someone with complete spider abilities.

title: The So-So Spiderman
review:
With everyone going gaga over this movie I guess I expected something more. To me, it was just another average day at the movies when seeing The Amazing Spider-Man and I don't think I will ever understand the hype.

First of all, "the untold story" I'm assuming is code word for "retelling the same origin story with a few tweaks." Sure there's a new love interest in the form of Gwen Stacy, played by Emma Stone, and Peter goes to High School instead of working for the Daily Bugle, but other than that it is the same story you saw in the original 2002 Spider-Man directed by Sam Raimi.

I will give the movie credit where it is due, the acting was very good. Despite my scepticism, Andrew Garfield proved to be an excellent Spider-Man and Peter Parker (although I still find it hard to believe someone that good looking was an outcast in school... just saying.)Spider-man is more comical and charismatic in this film than in all three prior films combined. However, Tobey Maguire will always embody Spider-Man for me in a way I don't think Andrew Garfield could ever touch. I've always enjoyed Emma Stone as an actress and she does play Gwen Stacy well, It's just that I found Gwen Stacy superfluous in that, she does nothing of genuine consequence other than creating the mixture which I'm sure someone else could have done. I understand that the movie needs a love interest, I just wish she would have been more involved. Their romance was uncomfortable for me. I know they're awkward teens but do they have to be THAT awkward?

Visually this film is stunning and is one of the few films I've seen where the 3D actually added something to the film. I also enjoyed the fact that Peter got visibly wounded, making his fight scenes more tense as you felt there was the real possibility of death. The "shadow" of Norman Osbourne over the film was also interesting. You never see him but you know he is waiting in the corners, creating a eerie tone whenever he is mentioned. However, the plot is nothing special, nor is the villain. The film promises to discuss the disappearance of Peter's parents but, after their departure within the first five minutes,they are never really mentioned again. In the end, The Amazing Spider-Man turns out to be just So-So.

title: Good, but not great rendering of Spider-Man
review: I was in my first year of school when the first Spider-Man film from 2002 was released. Since then, it has remained to be one of my favorite superhero films. The second one only got better, but the third just stank from start to finish. Coming off of that, a re-boot seemed to be the only way to go, but of course they made it too early. It's only been ten years since the first from 2002. That's my main complaint: the film decides to retell the origin story when I'm sure most of the audience remembers the first film. Aside from that, the acting is surprisingly good, the villain is pretty good, and the action doesn't disappoint. Just a couple dumb moments, otherwise a welcome re-boot that makes me want to see more, but please make it better.

title: Good, but not great.
review:
So I just got back from the movie, having expectations moderately high. I watched the commercial, saying it is, "The Top Movie in the World". That gave me some mixed messages I couldn't really comprehend.

I really liked Andrew Garfield when he played the role of Eduardo Saverin in The Social Network, so I was pleased to hear that he'd take on his first lead role. But with this, I was a bit disappointed.

PROS -It was more like the original comics -The fighting effects were well done

CONS -Garfield was too caught up in Peter Parker's attitude -The story jumped sometimes

There really isn't much to say about the film. I'm not saying it is terrible! I enjoyed most of it. But I don't see the real point of this recreation from the Tobey MacGuire series. But yes, it is an improvement in directing, but not the acting.

title: Great movie, but was there really any need for a remake?
review:
If you love, or even just like Spider-Man, and enjoy action, TASM will give you your money's worth. My only quibble is that Andrew Garfield is no Tobey Maguire, and Emma Stone is no Kirsten Dunst. They're a bit shallow in an otherwise entertaining film. But did this really need to be remade, or was this merely a substitute for the abandoned Spider-Man 4? I would have liked to have seen another sequel, but then again, a sequel would have been the same story anyway, so it wouldn't have made any difference. Even though I enjoyed watching the evil lizard, which is put to good use, it's nothing special. Since Peter Parker's aunt and uncle are secondary to the plot, they really aren't necessary (Sally Field's just here for the money) After all, the movie is about Spider-Man himself (and versus the villain), and mostly his love interest, but not his family.

*** out of ****

title: The Amazing Peter Parker
review:
As a reader of comics, I enjoy - and am used to - seeing new creative teams bringing a new vision for iconic characters, but rebooting the Spider-Man franchise a mere five years after Raimi's Spider-Man 3 was released, just felt too soon. By now we know the story of Peter Parker being bitten by a radioactive spider, quite well. Heck, we know it very well! Granted, Raimi's films had a camp tone to them, but it took its characters very seriously. It was this delicate blend that helped create a timelessness to those films, whereas TASM is obviously trying to be 'of its time'. For this reason I fear that in years to come TASM will still live in the shadow of the Raimi films.

That said, the first half of the film is a powerful drama on its own merit. 'Spider-Man' aside, the Parker household has enough emotional depth and warmth you quickly find yourself caring for these characters - credit due to a wonderful cast who delivered great performances. Garfield in particular delivers a performance of the frustrated teenager on the verge of young adulthood perfectly.

Webb's debut film, 500 Days of Summer, showed that he knows how to capture the emotional highs and lows of relationships flawlessly, and he's done so again with TASM. The film shines brightest when focused on its leads, Garfield and Stone. Their chemistry in undeniable and leaves you begging for more.

For a film trying to appeal to modern audiences, visually - it works. Delivering a style edging between the richness of 'Batman Begins' and the glitz 'n glamour of 'Kick Ass'; however, never quite reaching the heights of either.

At times, TASM feels tied down by its predecessor. The action is solid, but fails to offer the level of excitement and spectacle crafted in the Spider-Man 2 fight scenes between Spidey and Doc Ock. It also lacks memorable visual narratives as seen in the previous films, and so nothing really stays with you; for instance, Spider-Man 2 manages to sum up the inner conflict of the hero by having Spider-Man's mask torn in two, showing one half as the determined masked hero and the other as the vulnerable Peter Parker - a strong, thoughtful image; something sorely missing in this film. Apart from an inspired Stan Lee cameo, which shows the artistic ingenuity and endearing humour of Webb, as seen in 500 Days, there's not really any 'wow' moments, which is disappointing considering the film is call The Amazing Spider-Man.

The trailer promised 'the untold story', referring to Peter's father; however, what we get is the introduction to the untold story. The mysteries surrounding Peter's father and his work are the main drive which sets the story in motion, only for it to come to a complete halt and not be mentioned for the entire second half of the film. It isn't until a sequel baiting, mid-credit scene that this plot is picked up again. Fortunately, they've set up the players well and created a Spider-Man world I look forward to see expanded upon, so a sequel is more than welcome. And in turn, it isn't frustrating that there's 'sequel bait' littered throughout.

Although the spectacle of The Amazing Spider-Man is enjoyable but somewhat underwhelming, the film makes up for its shortcomings with its tremendous cast and weighty emotional punch - which is unsurpassed by previous Marvel films. Ultimately, as a standalone film TASM is quite forgettable, and now has to rely on its sequels to deliver the goods in order for this new series to become relevant.

Rating: 7/10 as 6/10 seems too low

title: it's like a family's generations, deteriorating gradually
review: this is a horrible movie with very bad and boring screenplay, bad directing, bad sound track (background sound/music), and most of all, the worst casting job! the young actor who played the spiderman was a a terrible choice done by a lousy casting agency. this young actor got a very unlikable face and a low i.q. expression, his mouth is always half opened and i just couldn't find anything special of his acting. he's not energetic enough to be a spiderman, looked quite immature and spiritless, even when he's not a spiderman but a nerd like person, i just couldn't place him to play the spiderman role. this is a very boring film with horrible scenario, storyline and plot. the whole movie was just so predictable and at the same time, most of the scenes were nighttime dark. the supporting female actor was not too good either. she looked like about 10 years older than the little brother kiddy spiderman. this is a movie that making the summertime feel more bored than ever. save your money and time and go to magic mountain fun park to have some thrills.

title: Not quite amazing, but very damn good.
review: The biggest glaring issue "The Amazing Spider-Man" falls to is the inconsistency of its special effects: despite getting glammed-up by the Hollywood treatment, the film's CGI waxes and wanes from sleek and stylish action sequences to Windows 98-generated goofiness. It's a small crack in this movie's rather impressive visual exoskeleton, but one that is majorly detrimental to some of the fight scenes and larger set pieces. Still, it doesn't take away too much from what this film is all about: incredibly digestible entertainment value. This is the Spider-Man adventure Stan Lee certainly wants us to see, and the one we as audiences have been waiting for. "The Amazing Spider-Man" serves up exactly what every summer moviegoer seeks: a film that combines the best parts of the franchise's campy melodrama, honest ideals, and web- slinging fun. And when all is said and done, the effort proves to be not just satisfying, but absolutely heroic.

title: The Movie I was waiting for
review:
i've seen many reviews in the internet, i am a spider-man fan, not the i have all the comic books spider-man fan, but a regular spider-man fan, who knows who is who, seen the TV shows, the raimi films and love the whole universe around it.

As a regular spider-man fan i must say, this is the best interpretation of the origin story i could ever ask for. I'm in love with this movie... and you should too.

First things first, they do take some creative liberties, but nothing too big to upset you. The ambientation, realization of power, chemistry, cast, acting a CGI were all there in perfect unison, not too much of any, delivering the perfect origin movie.

Second, yes they retold the whole story, but you know what? after the reimi films they had to!, the origin story in the previous films was soo cartoonish that nobody could relate to spider-man, he was dumbed down, shame on them.

third, the humor is the only part where i cant be happy, yeah the jokes were there and worked, but they were too few and its spider-man we are talking about, he is practically a comedian in tights.

i'll keep this review like this, with no spoilers, just few last pointers: Garfield and stone chemistry WAS BRILLIANT!, the action scenes were the out of this world(there was a spider trick that was particularly funny, but you'll know when you see it) and the ambientation makes you feel in the real world, making the experience incredibly relatable.

8/10 just for the lack of humor, but that can be worked in the sequels where freakin uncle Ben doesn't die.

you liked iron man because it felt real and amazing? then you'll love this movie, GARFIELD IS THE REAL SPIDERMAN! and after the theater you'll crave for more.

title: A much less clever and engaging take on the spider-man origin story
review:
THIS REVIEW IS AIMED AT READERS WHO HAVE ALREADY SEEN THE MOVIE AND ARE CURIOUS ABOUT OTHERS OPINIONS, NOT PEOPLE TRYING TO SEE WHETHER THE AMAZING SPIDER MAN IS WORTH YOUR TIME AND MONEY. SPOILER: IT'S NOT!!

Despite my unfavorable opinion of this movie, I'm going to start off with what I liked about The Amazing Spider-man. First off, as far as visuals go, this movie was well directed. The first person shots, segments of spidey web slinging around the city, and some cool action parts like where spidey dodges those cops bullets at point blank range, are pretty much the only things I enjoyed about the amazing spider man. I'll say this once, all the crazy good special effects and cool spider- man action in the world can't carry a movie, especially a movie with an extremely inconsistent and tensionless tone and a completely redundant feel like The Amazing Spider-man.

My biggest problem with this movie is that it covered the same plot points as The Original Spider-man, but did it all in a much less clever and memorable way. Did Spider-man really need to be re-booted? Did the new film really do enough to distinguish itself from itself predecessor and add any layers of emotional depth or intelligence to the origin story? My personal opinion is that what it did do to distinguish itself inevitably flawed the movie beyond repair.

Lets start with the tone of the movie. The makers said they wanted to bring more realism and a darker more 'dark knight' like tone to the spider-man reboot. But at the same time they brought in a more comic- book-esque sense of humor to the spider-man character(often times spidey would remind me of the live action teenaged mutant ninja turtles)let's get this straight: Batman is batman and his character is inherently more compatible with a darker tone and the spider-man from the comic books(which is the one the makers were trying to bring to the film) doesn't mesh well at all with this type of tone. This is what kept me from getting emotionally invested at all in the movie and what kept the whole thing from working.

The villain is portrayed by a great actor, but isn't given any well written dialogue or any really interesting form of character development. He wants to turn everyone else in the city into a lizards.....because he wants to strengthen humanity and eradicate all weakness....and all this his motivations are exposed through him talking to a camera...I just never felt the characters plight or his motivation if anything getting even with the corporate A-holes who screwed him would have made better character motivation..... oh, and he talks to himself and hears voices in his head(William Dafoe's green goblin anyone?)And at least the green goblin had an intensity to his character, a certain craziness and determination. You kind of feared what he would do next because he's a crazy technological mastermind.. Doctor Conners turns into a 7 foot lizard and throws stuff around and chases spiderman....LAME. Was the whole 'turn everyone into a lizard with my machine' scheme really best suited for that type of villain?

The original spider man felt...original. In the original, peter was screwed out of thousands of dollars by a greedy wrestling manager and then let the thief get away out of revenge..you could feel the regret and pain in tobey maguires spider man as his uncle ben died before his eyes and called out his name with his dying breathes. In the reboot, peter's moral compass ran eschew over a bottle of chocolate milk -_- and Uncle Ben moronically tried to grab the thiefs dropped gun out of some 'delusion of grandeur'impulse and got shot. The original Uncle Ben was confronted by the thief and was shot when he refused to accomplice him. Which Uncle Ben do you like better? I like Martin Sheen and Sally Field but they were miscasted. And what was up with that voicemail from Uncle Ben at the end? "So come on home Peter, because you're my hero. Let me just talk about things that are only in context at the end of the movie when I'm dead and not at all while I'm actually saying them." LAME. SO LAME. This whole movie felt like a huge waste of time for me and for everyone involved in making it. This is no refreshing or clever new take on the origin story. It's a huge mess that looks good.

title: Not a worthwhile watch
review:
It's never an easy job for a director who's trying to make a movie out of a legendary comic book franchise. It's harder still when you're trying to reboot an already successful movie franchise based on this comic book character. So I'd like to give Marc Webb the benefit of the doubt and assume that it was a total misunderstanding of the concept of Spiderman rather than a lack of talent on his part that led to this movie being an utter disappointment (Though another plausible explanation could be that he might've been inebriated throughout the shooting and post production of the movie).

To be fair to Webb, one can't say he didn't try. He has tried deviating from the original plot line of the Spiderman comics to avoid predictability and monotony in this movie (he even borders on changing some facts that are sacrosanct to the franchise). However, he seems to have absolutely no clue as to the target audience of this movie as well as their intellectual capacity. The story has some gaping plot holes and the character development (especially spidey's) lacks a lot of the elements that made spiderman one of the most popular underdogs in the marvel universe.

Spiderman was popular with the masses because of his humble background (that people could relate to) and the raging battle between conflicting emotions that constantly raged in his mind (quite akin to Tobey McGuire's portrayal of a PMSing woman in spiderman's body). The only emotion that's been portrayed in this movie is when he tells his girl friend that he likes to kiss her.

There's not much to complain about the acting, but each character in the story as well as their influence on the leads is so poorly defined that the audience barely has a chance to connect with them. There's no way of feeling the bond between Peter and his uncle and aunt and absolutely no portrayal of how much of a downtrodden geek Parker happens to be. Also, one of the most crucial characters in the franchise has been completely cut out of the story, much like Peeves the poltergeist was cut out of Harry Potter. Note to the director – J.Jonah Jameson is far from expendable. Spend less time explaining how the costume was designed and work a little extra on helping your audience understand the characters (also – get a bigger budget so you can afford a Jameson)

The plot of the movie was so weak it would've but a Kamal R Khan movie to shame. The same old story of a good guy going bad by accident and going around terrorizing people for the most ridiculous of reasons. Why the villain would painstakingly create a 3D walkthrough explaining his glorious plot to any and all passers by in his secret hideout is well beyond my understanding. I feel that the drunken monkey on Columbia's payroll that suggested this scene is quite overpaid.

The fight scenes and climax in the movie as well as the pathetic attempts at infusing comedy into these didn't do much for the cause either. There's not a single scene in the movie that registers as impressive to the viewer – least of all the one with the cranes. So, if you're watching this movie just for the 3D experience, don't! It's not stereoscopic and is absolutely worthless.

So, to sum things up – here's what you can expect from 'The Amazing Spiderman':

Pros

Most theatres today are air-conditioned.

You can try getting to first base during the kissing scenes in the movie.

Some theatres have tasty, overpriced snacks and comfortable seats.

Not at all risky for people with heart problems.

The last scene with a web shooting straight for your head makes you welcome the feeling of impending doom with open arms and is worth 0.01% of the money you spent.

You help the producers recover the money spent on the movie so that they can continue living their extravagant lifestyles. Good karma keeps your circle positive.

Still a better love story than Twilight.

Cons

You can't un-watch the movie after it's over.

Emma Stone isn't half as hot as Kirsten Dunst was in the earlier spider man.

Your girlfriend might fall in love with Andrew Garfield (consider this a pro if she's currently in love with Edward Cullen).

Worthless 3D, laughable plot – not appealing to kids or adults (I'm a bit of both), mediocre acting and pathetic overall package.

The game on the movie (which is friggin awesome) isn't offered at a discount to those who made the mistake of watching it.

Your mother's going to ask you to clean your room after seeing how neat and tidy the sewers in the movie were (I'm not joking – they've got freshwater springs in there – talk about attention to detail).

Hope this helps you decide whether you want to catch the movie at the box office, buy the DVD (yeah right!), or illegally download the movie via torrents (Which is very wrong and something I would seriously recommend against. Remember – with great download speeds comes great responsibility!).

title: Nothing Amazing
review:
So you think they would kept the story going after Spider-Man 3 well thanks to the bad reviews Sony and Marvel decided on a Reboot, Big Mistake.

The Amazing Spider-Man retells how Peter Parker Becomes Spider-Man after the death of his Uncle.

But it clearly was poorly cast with Andrew Garfield a no body as Spider-Man my only guess is that he bribed the casting director for the role because he was so awful that I wanted to turn off the movie from the get go.

Emma Stone plays Gwen Stacy, the new love interest of Peter Parker I can't think of anything to say about her performance I mean her character was pretty boring.

What really sets me off about this film is that while the Lizard is one of my favorite Spider-man villains they really wronged him in this film making him look like a Dinosaur wannabe with boring C G I effects.

The acting in the film is forced to say the least nothing worth a single reward nor should it.

Plus there are far too many gore scenes from this film and it was unneeded so that pretty much ruin the film for me.

The writing is so bad that I should have turn off the film from the start because I could have wrote a story better than this.

So this film was unneeded and was a awful idea to reboot the series all because of one film, Curse you Spider man 3 for forcing Sony and Marvel to reboot this series with a terrible actor.

I wouldn't even recommend it for a rental.

I give The Amazing Spider-Man a 1 out of 10.

title: And I thought Spiderman 3 was bad!!!
review:
This has got to be the worst Spiderman film I have ever seen, nothing about this film is worthwhile and I will admit to say that I was looking forward to it. I have been a Spiderman fan all my life and I appreciated the early Spiderman films by Nicholas Hammond, yes they were cheesy and campy but it was still entertaining.

Then we had the excellent Sam Raimi Spiderman films, not only was Tobey Maguire an excellent choice for Spiderman but he looked and acted just like Peter Parker would. The first and in particular the second movie defined the hero that Spiderman is and yes while the third film was bloated it was still entertaining to watch.

Now onto The Amazing Spiderman, truth to be told I had no problem with Andrew Garfield replacing Maguire, the same can be said about Emma Stone replacing Kirsten Dunst, however the film itself doesn't feel like a Spiderman movie. The first half hour is basically about Peter Parker's deceased parents, however we don't get a conclusion as to what happen to them, the story just disappears. Most importantly though Garfield's Peter Parker is totally off the mark, he shouts at his Uncle Ben and Aunt May, spends most of his time on his skateboard and only seems interested in dating Gwen Stacy. Heck, even the scene where Uncle Ben dies felt totally wrong.

I know this is just based on a comic book but at least keep it to the source material, what happen to the famous line "with great power comes great responsibility" I just could not connect with this version of Peter Parker at all and it doesn't get any better when he puts on the suit either. As far as Dr Connors goes, I think Rhys Ifans was reasonable as the doctor but once he becomes the Lizard, any credibility he has is thrown out the window, obviously a villain such as the Lizard is not going to look realistic but the CGI here is unbelievably bad.

On a happier note, it was good to see Martin Sheen and Sally Field as Uncle Ben and Aunt May respectively. Dennis Leary as Captain Stacy was not too bad either. Again, I am sad to say that this Spiderman film is not worth watching, I watched it once and I won't be watching it again, in fact now would be a good time to revisit Sam Raimi's Spiderman films again.

If I can think of one good thing to say about this Spiderman movie, it would be the web shooters which were pretty cool (and faithful to the comics) but then that's not saying much about the overall movie itself.

title: Worst Spider-Man ever!!!
review: Worst Spider-Man ever!!! The main actor does not fit the role of any superhero. Everyone who watched this movie truly wondered how He get this role??? The only thing that pulls the film - it's special effects, but even here there is much to grow. Just really did not like the idea of ​​devices on hand that produce webs. Besides lovers actors tightened set of stamps in the film, as well as early exposure of the individual of the main hero. My biggest fear is that this actor will play in the Avengers and will do even worse that great movie!!!!

title: Very awful movie
review: I am giving this 1 for effort of the actors and expense went to. This is the worst movie I have seen for a long time. title: The Amazing Twilight
review:
* * No Spoilers - Although I'd love to spoil it so you may not see it and earn your beautiful money * *

Oh My God...what was that?

OK, we gotit Hollywood. It's final. No more adult super-heroes (except batman,and some x-men maybe), no more serious plots, no more sci-fi movies to entertain people over 18-20 years old. Age groups below 18 prevail and the sooner we admit it, the less money we will spend in fancy Twilight-ish garbages like this.

There must be something like a disease upon all producers - script writers - directors. The "Money from Nothing" syndrome. Since there isn't any new idea for a sci-fi blockbuster around, what they do? They remake the remakes of the remakes. And they call it "Reboot".

And now they do it the "Twilight" way.

For those (is there any?) who don't know, Twilight is an updated Beverly Hills 90210 spoof for little children and early teenagers, where vampires look pretty, beautiful and amazing, clean and shiny, to the extend that make you wanna be a vampire instead of a human. Oh, and they dress like top models.

  • After "rebooting" (= making money by "executing" the original idea) Star Wars (Phantom Money - sorry George, Menace, and the other two parodies), Star Trek (you know, that one with that coxcomb spoiled boy pretending to be Kirk),and Alien (quiz: is there anyone who remembers anything from script-less Poop-etheus?), - after shamelessly destroying comic heroes like the Avengers (Cowboys-like superheroes running here & there for actually no reason), Captain - baby-face - America, Thor (yes, that wrestling figure pretending to be ancient God)and numerous others, twilight-spidey had to be next, only 10 years after his previous (and absolutely better) remake.


Either sci-fi show-biz is now run by teenagers, either is run by dotard old idiots with Alzheimer's. There can't be any other explanation for this unbelievable mess.

Helloooooo producers and filmmakers, I have news for you: in case you haven't noticed, old sci-fi products like Star Trek, Star Wars, Alien(s), 2001: A Space Odyssey, Blade Runner, even Matrix etc are STILL best sellers on DVD/BR, and people still go to theaters to watch any new (3D,etc) version. And YOU KNOW WHY? It's not just the new ideas or scripts, or their director's talent....it's because even if they weren't, THEY WERE LOOKING serious! They had P-L-O-T-S, and they were addressing adult people as well.

And in case you forget, they brought MONEY, lot of MONEY to whoever invested on them, if this is more convincing for you!! But I guess you know. But you don't care. If you can make money out of "Amazing" garbages like this, why bother to make a good movie? It's like they've decided that, regarding sci-fi cinema, the only valuable target group are only kids. What about the others? Well, they can buy comics or watch older sci-fi movies at home. Period.

The Myth: As we grow older, is getting more and more difficult for us to "buy" sci-fi, so we become more critic and suspicious.

The Truth behind the Myth: As we grow older, it's getting easier for us to recognize pure, money oriented garbage from honest inspirational sci-fi attempts.

Advice: If you really want to watch "The Amazing Spiderman", be smart and go buy a comic instead of throwing your money for this cheap silly nonsense.

Unless of course if you are 8 years old.

title: Will cause a proper debate between those who prefer this, and those who love the prior trilogy
review: Peter is a typical high-school student, if a little nerdy. He is bullied, but unlike the Maguire version, you like him, relate to him, and he's not just awkward and quiet all the time. He has a crush on Gwen(who is not just "the girl the lead will end up with", she has a vital role, personality, and she's incredibly charming and beautiful), and she may just like him, too... and you believe that, because she's slightly geeky, herself(and the relationship between them is part of the emotional core that is the film's greatest strength... you really get into this, never bored because of how much you care, and it leaves an impact on you; it's a drama where the protagonist happens to be a costumed superhero, not the other way around). Their puppy love is endearing, and I defy any young straight male to not fall for her. One day, because of his inherent stupidity(...yeah, this is a bit more of a teenage-y take on the material, and it is dumbed down... the car thief uses a gadget to break into the vehicle(in the trailer, the one that also lets you one that in this, the wit of the titular hero is actually present, and *funny*), which doesn't contradict his intelligence(hey, he's a kid!), he's bitten by a Scienced-Up spider. He gets to figure out his powers, and soon becomes a masked vigilante(for an actual reason, in this one). Dr. Connors is a kind man who wants to help those who have lost limbs or the like(including himself), and he becomes The Lizard from splicing animal DNA with that of reptiles... and... turns completely evil, which is a bit unfortunate, as it would be more interesting with a tragic villain. What he lacks in shades of grey he makes up for in being freaking terrifying. He provides the scariest and most tense moments in all four films(I suppose the old ones didn't really try for that), and the fact that he's clearly *smart*, not just "an animal", really seals the deal(and they give him a nice, expressive, monstrous face). He will have to be stopped, but Spider-Man has to be careful, as George Stacy, captain of the corps, has sent the police(oh yeah, they exist in this universe! You know, the Raimi ones had me forgetting that...) to arrest him(goes against the comics? Sure, however, it creates tenable conflict, makes sense and really brings forth this, another of the strong characters). This is a more realistic approach, and thus it gets to be dark. The origin is retold, and it is less mature than the 2004 sequel(remake of the first one? Nah, it takes some of the scenes and expands upon them). Uncle Ben and Aunt May are real people, and clearly an old married couple. This doesn't really get goofy. The mystery leaves us hanging, for better or worse. This is well-paced. The action is excellent, very tight, we feel the blows, and it has the elements we'd want - webbings, swinging(we've seen that before, but this is the only one where there is a sequence of it that is genuinely powerful), mid-air fighting and heroics(something that we see come naturally, over time, to Parker, not just "well, if I were in a graphic novel, I'd save people, so why not!"). FX are amazing, pun intended. The 3D is admittedly barely present, and frankly, if you want to save the extra expense, you're not missing anything by just watching a regular version. There is a lot of bloody violence(really pushing the PG-13 rating), disturbing content, and a little moderate language in this. I recommend this very much to any fan of the source, of this genre, of those involved and even those who liked the other flicks. 8/10

title: I like it
review: I understand why people don't like the amazing Spider-Man 1 and 2. To me it was an OK reboot. I think it could have been better though. But it tried it best to be what it was. The film deserves some crop and Andrew Garfield did his best with the character. 8/10

title: True to its roots- A Super Hero Comic Book Movie
review: Almost as if lifted out of Amazing Fantasy #15 . Some scenes were right out of Stan Lees original version and Spiderman looked like John Buscmea drew him...Peter Parker looked like Peter Parker...There was a story and not just a SFX-CFX slug fest. Spiderman wise cracked . The movie was like reading a few issues of Spiderman ...penned by Stan and drawn by John Buscema. Of course some of the elements are missing: The Daily Bugle and J. Jonah Jameson. the Wrestling fight... but then those elements have been covered by the first installments. But overall this is one of the best Comic Book movies (true to the Comic Book roots) I have seen. This Spiderman and more so this Peter Parker is how I always imagined these Characters. I am a Comic book fan since the late 60ties and have not missed a single Spider Man comic since then and to me the original stories penned by Stan are still the best. The movie strikes a nice balance between action and story.

title: Nothing to set it apart from the 2002 movie
review:
I give this movie a 6. Frankly I was hoping for something much better. I was hoping for something that would really make this movie different from the franchise started in 2002. Something that would really make it worth watching since it's only been 5 years since a Spiderman movie came out. Well you know what they say about wishes, and hopes don't you? You can hope in one hand and take a number 2 in the other hand, and see which one fills up first. Yeah, nothing new or great here.

I guess you could say the story line is a tad different. They put Peter Parker's (Andrew Garfield) parents into the story. They also got rid of Mary Jane, in favor of a new love interest, Gwen (Emma Stone). They also remade Peter as a smart, loner, social outcast type (You know, like one of those kids that just might bring a gun to school), instead of just the nerdy geek with a camera.

Everyone knows the rest of the story by now. A socially awkward boy that lives with his aunt and uncle, gets bit by genetically experimental spider which gives him incredible spider like abilities. His uncle gets killed and he decides to avenge his death, and become a vigilante super hero. In the end Peter has to choose between being a super hero and being with the girl he loves.

I thought that maybe one reason they made this film so shortly after the last Toby Maguire trilogy (2002, 2004, 2007) might be to take a darker more sinister, and less corny version ala the Dark Knight franchise. While this one may have hinted that they wanted to go there in a few scenes it just never does. It still stays pretty corny. If you are going to make a film like this , Please have something original to offer and go for it. This movie to me looks and feels as though it was one of the last 3 films, but with different faces.

Andrew Garfield really adds and brings nothing, and I would say that both him and Tobey Maguire did an equally poor job. Ditching Kirsten Dunst was a good move as she is one of the most overrated actresses in Hollywood, and Emma Stone was probably the best actor in this whole movie so clearing out Mary Jane didn't hinder it. The CGI was overdone and that is one of the pet peeves I have with almost all movies these days.

In the end this movie was completely unnecessary, especially when there was a trilogy put out just 5 years ago. Sounds to me like the studio just wanted to pull one over on us and make a quick buck. This movie looks and feels like everybody involved with the previous movies just threw it together with some out takes of the last ones, and there is nothing to distinguish it as anything any better or worse.

I give it a 6, watchable, but it has nothing really different from the older 3 movies. If you want to watch a great, original, super hero movie, leave this one until you have exhausted all the others and rent Kick-Ass (2010) instead, and keep your eyes open for Kick-Ass 2 in June 2013.

Like my reviews, Hate em? Comments, Hate mail, or want a specific DVD reviewed just e-mail me at: subliminal.lithium@gmail.com

title: Spectacular!!!!!!
review:
Wow, at first I thought it was going to be just another generic reboot of Spider-man, but I was totally blown away with the script, timing, humor, acting, and special effects were perfect. Bravo to the actors and filmmakers!! I loved it! I feel this version of Spider-man is more to the comic than the Sam Raimi's version because Peter Parker is supposed to be kind of a nerdy, bookworm science geek besides a photographer. Also, the fact that Peter Parker now uses a device for his web (like the comic) instead of the web coming out of his skin (like the Sam Raimi's version) makes more sense now because he's slowly perfecting his craft. Plus he uses his technical skills he's learned from researching to build his costume seems more believable. Besides the costume design, Spider-man's personality again seems closer to the comic because he tries to be sarcastic and also is being human as well. He gets hurt where as Tobey as Spider-man seems to have superhuman strength without really having to struggle much (except with the villains). Andrew as Spider-man however seems realistic. There was a scene in the movie where he allows himself to be shown without the mask and he takes off his mask to prove to a kid whose scared that he is only human. I feel this is what Spider-man movie should've been instead of a sappy, cheezy, Spider-man storyline Sam Raimi directed, not that I didn't enjoy Sam Saimi's version of spider-man, but it wasn't as deep or sophisticated.

Last thing I would like to mention is that there are those ignorant morons who don't know the Spider-man comic books and criticizing the cast that it's nothing but a simple reboot. Even though Peter Parker's love interest isn't Mary Jane, Gwen Stacy IS Spider-man's first love interest before MJ in the comics, and Gwen's father's death IS correct (and I have that comic, it's worth a lot of money) because he dies in the comic as well! They need to understand the comic before criticizing the characters...read the darn comic, tired of this!!!

title: Best Spider-Man Movie To Date!
review:
This movie is not only the best Spider-Man movie I've seen, but maybe even the best movie I've ever seen, mostly because it blew my mind, and it reached far over the top of my expectations. The music is even better and far more emotional than the trilogy's. The effects are top-notch. I could barely see, when there were special effects in it. The relationship between Gwen and Peter made me smile. !!SPOILER!! And I cried when Uncle Ben died. I didn't cry in the 2002 one, because Toby's cry was a little bit funny, and I didn't see it as a overly sad moment, because I couldn't take the movie seriously. The thing with the untold story sounds pretty interesting. Many people complained about the secret not being revealed in the movie.I know, that they mentioned the untold story would be revealed, but I think, that more details would be revealed in the next couple of movies. And some details were actually explained in this movie. For instance, we get to hear, why Peters dad suddenly stopped the project about curing. That's one brick in the puzzle. More would be revealed in the next movies. The only complain I have, is Sony. Sony kept an eye over Marc, when he made the movie, to make sure he didn't make the movie too much Spider-Man 2002-ish. If it wasn't for Sony, this movie could actually have been much better. Sony, I just wanna say, that when it's a reboot, you basically start from scratch, so it means, that you should not compare it to the other trilogy!!! It's a reboot. Deal with it. Well, at least it is the best movie I've seen. And the ending of the movie (Final swing) is the best scene in movie history! The slow-mo effects, the emotion, the positions, the everything!

This is a movie, I'll never forget.

title: Amazing Isn't Good Enough To Describe This Movie/ Incredible!
review: I went to see this movie at the midnight showing, and yes I am a HUGE Spider-man fan so I may be a little biased but i went to see it multiple times and did see a few mistakes so this review will be reliable! The Amazing Spiderman is the reboot of Sony's acclaimed spiderman movies, and in my opinion, they created a new peak for the movies. Sam Raimi's spiderman flicks were good at points but going back to see them, they are now just very silly and stupid. The Amazing Spiderman is a very spectacular interpretation of the comics. Even though the producers took from a few other comic series, this spiderman flick did stay true to the comics and left me crying of happiness in the end. The story of how Peter Parker is yes, retold but in the true way. Where he makes the web-shooters! (Not where he can freaking shoot unrealistic webs out of his wrists! Like What the heck!) Which is kind of rushed in ways, but I think is necessary because of the "oh I get it" factors that come from the quick shots. Other than that the movie is very well timed and edited. The cast is AMAZING!! Andrew Garfield plays a great Spiderman. All of the twitches and random, qwerky, little things that he does just add to making him a great Peter Parker. Peter Parker is a geek, an outcast, a nerd! I expect the actors to portray that well and thats exactly what Andrew did. Also as Spiderman he makes great smart-a remarks and shows off the strength and sheer skill of Spiderman perfectly. Emma Stone plays a wonderful Gwen Satcy and actually has brains as a character unlike the Sam Raimi movies. All aroudn this movie is great! I'd give it six gazillion thumbs up if I had that many thumbs, hope this review helps and I hope all of you readers make the right decision in choosing to see this movie!!

title: Good remake...but
review: This is a good re-make or re tread of the original SPIDERMAN. Why the re-make I'm not sure, but there several differences and some good casting, although ANDREW GARFIELD wasn't all that great and EMMA STONE was hard to understand because of her almost whisper of a voice. Is something wrong with her? For those who never saw the original should see this one for some amazing effects and 3-D does work for this one. Good to see SALLY FIELD on the big screen again and not looking none to good which is very realistic. Actually I know this is a cartoon of sorts, two things bothered me. How did the scientist set up a lair with computers, electricity etc. in a sewer????? No one noticed him taking all those items down there and how could anyone possibly have done that?? OK..A cartoon. Secondly, the hallway and several classrooms were destroyed by the fight with the Liazard and Spiderman. At the end when they're back in school, everything looks completely untouched!!!!! No way could the damage have been fixed in a few days time. OK..it's a cartoon!!

title: What a waste
review:
Where do I begin. After growing up with spider man cartoons & watching the first three films starring Dunst & Maguire one tends to fall in love with the whole concept of boy being bitten, getting the woman of his dreams & fighting crime until happily ever after. This film however was a major disappointment. Every aspect of this film from the script to the acting & direction lacked credibility. The new kid on the block, Andrew Garfield hardly knows how to act. The story line is very predictable. The worst part was that the hero doesn't even get the girl. I was unfortunate to watch it in the theatre & that too in 3D. There were hardly any 3D effects. Film makers will go to any extent to squeeze out money from our pockets. 

My verdict 3/10

title: Enjoyable nostalgia
review:
It proves problematic analysing this film without comparing it and Sam Raimi's 2002 approach to the same character. These similarities and differences are both detrimental and admirable to Marc Webb's picture.

As one of 2012's most anticipated films, 'The Amazing Spider-Man' suffers greatly from it consciousness. Excuse the pun, but the tone during the 136 minutes a certain 'Spidey-sense' about itself; knowledgeable of its existence as a reboot, and not a new trilogy. The unfortunate consequences of this are within the nostalgic narrative, which we all remember from a decade ago. Not only does this film follow the original story, but it's aware of it, causing the evolution of Spider-Man to be rushed as if the director is saying, "you've seen it before, let's just swing through this part of the story". There is more to see from this series, reportedly, at least a trilogy, though the first of three could have been condensed into the opening title sequence, as the formulaic story has already been tested once before in cinema by Raimi. Nevertheless, the love story between Peter Parker and Gwen Stacey presents itself as more convincing than what we saw from Raimi's films with Mary-Jane Watson. Our female love interest (portrayed by Emma Stone) actually provides the plot with some importance, and does not need to be saved by our hero in the climax as her predecessor (Kirsten Dunst) repeatedly did in all three of Raimi's pictures. In its entirety, the film feels as if it is an introduction to a story, the blurb of your favourite novel, forgotten, because you enjoyed what followed so much more.

The angle taken by Webb and the cast can be applauded. The choreography, characterisation and dialogue have successfully adapted to the approach of having Peter Parker becoming Spider-Man whilst still in high school. Andrew Garfield portrays the character as arrogant, rebellious and at time reckless, in both personality and acrobatic style (give credit to his stunt doubles also), hugely contrasting from what we saw from Tobey Maguire. Both actors provide various memorable qualities to the comic book hero, contrastingly so, meaning preference between the two is no clear choice, simply down to opinion. There are a number of factors to consider when selecting a winner. On one hand, 'The Amazing Spider-Man' explores the origin story of the character which is yet to be completely revealed, leaving the anticipation for fans for future sequels. Furthermore, we encounter a far superior romance story between Gwen Stacey and Peter Parker so in terms to Spider-Man's humanity, Garfield's interpretation wins out. However, Maguire simply fits the costume better, and makes for a better Spider-Man. We can contribute much this to his voice and the CGI of the character used by studio. Furthermore, the actually story of Spider-Man just does not feel very heroic this time around. The suit itself though with a warm home- made approach to it, bluntly worded does not look as good as in Raimi's series. Though we shouldn't necessarily judge a hero by his mask right? Well depending on what the mask represents. Any suit, whether it is Captain America's, Batman's or Spider-Man's should be a symbol for what these characters believe in, yet this film explores the use of the suit in a continuous quest for vengeance by the character, consequently signifying less of an American hero as we saw from Raimi. Webbing together what exactly this means; Garfield wins the Peter Parker award, while Maguire wins the Spider-Man trophy, resulting in my personal favouritism leaning towards Maguire.

"Who am I?" The primary theme of identity is highly emphasised by Webb, as the character attempts to deal with a variety of relatable human and superhero problems. He never really does find himself within the film, yet indicates a certain growth in character because of the adversity he faces, often from his own hubris, making him a tragic hero who is required to fathom that ''with great power, comes great responsibility".

There are certainly aspects of this film that are an evident improvement from what Raimi did. Conversely, many components that I adored in the previous series are severely missed, making it intricate to establish a definite preference between the two. The music in this reboot is a satisfactory bungalow when up against the Empire State that was the score by Danny Elfman in the first two Spider-Man films, and Christopher Young in the third. No disrespect to James Horner whose contribution to 'The Amazing Spider-Man's' score is excellent, but with the will to compare, it's like a butter knife to a gun fight.

I do not wish to bore those reading, as endless comparisons between the two and analysis of the stand alone film could provoke me to write a dissertation of needless proportions. Therefore, I will conclude by stating my comprehension of this review's bias, due to my obsession with the comic book hero, I almost refrained from observing its many imperfections. However, after watching it three times already I felt I have identified 'The Amazing Spider-Man' as a motion picture that had great potential to reboot an already successful film franchise. Was it necessary for Webb to reboot? Yes! I feel that he has introduced a new story for Peter Parker/Spider-Man that was not considered by Raimi. The execution may not have been perfect, yet this instalment does provide a great sense of well performed humour, action and emotion that perhaps is only existent due to the 50 year anniversary of Stan Lee's and Marvel's most successful character. This highly enjoyable reboot will hopefully instigate a more original story is subsequent sequels. 6/10 is perhaps too critical of Webb's work, yet the almost identical narrative to 2002 is this film's biggest downfall, as our villain in Dr. Curtis Connors/The Lizard acquires indistinguishable motives to that of Norman Osborn as the Green Goblin. It is Marvelous nonetheless, to see that the adored character Spider-Man has yet to spin his last Webb in cinema.

title: Someone Please Let Christopher Nolan to Takeover!
review:
This is my third disappointment with the spider series. Can't say it is really a waste of time but it is far from being a good one. I certainly hope for someone to takeover this project/series & do it like what Christopher Nolan did to Batman series.

If you haven't seen the latest two Batman movies buy/rent the DVDs right away & see it for yourself. These movies have a taste. This is what spider-man fails to deliver. It tries gives you another perspective about Peter Parker which is over-dramatized by Andrew Garfield. I believe he is a poor choice for Peter Parker, however, still far better than Tobey Maguire.

If you have a minute for spidey, please share this with your friends. Let Christopher Nolan to takeover!

title: There Is Nothing Amazing About This Spiderman!!!!
review:
"The Amazing Spiderman" is a thoroughly unnecessary and quite pedestrian re-boot of a re-boot. Was this movie really necessary? No of course not, but in the dwindling days of Hollywood's ability to create new, original and imaginative movies, this is what passes for an "original" idea.

While re-makes are not something new, Sam Raimi's "Spider-Man" re-boot franchise is only a few years old, and DID NOT warrant yet another franchise, as I said, a re-boot of a re-boot.

People will point to the "Batman" franchise as an example. Still, there are some differences there, after Tim Burton's first two exciting entries, Joel Schumacher managed to water down and destroy the "Batman" franchise. Christopher Nolan took Batman and gave the Dark Knight his own spin and interpretation, making him much darker and more menacing, straddling the fine line between villain and hero. So I understood the rationale for doing that, besides Nolan delivered two excellent movies so far "Batman Begins" and "The Dark Knight". We'll see what "The Dark Knight Rises" will be like.

Personally I never liked Spidermans as a superhero, frankly he's just not that exciting, a guy who sticks to walls and shoots thread out of his wrists...the same goes for Superman, not to keen on him either. There is no sense of danger, of conflict emanating from these characters, and most of the popular superheroes, be they Marvel or DC etc. "Batman" is the only one that I find intriguing (from the popular ones), he himself does not have superpowers of his own, yet he has such a classic design, one that can make him look as a superhero but also a masked vigilante at the same time. With Batman you never really know where you stand...is he good or bad?

For these reasons, I prefer the more complicated characters like "Blade", "Spawn" and "The Punisher". I did not like Raimi's movies, nor this one. I'd rather choose movies like "Sin City", "The Crow", "300", "V-For Vendetta" and "Watchmen" than any of the Spiderman ones.

I know that I'm probably in the minority here, but I did not think that this movie was necessary in any way, shape or form, nor did I think that it was a particularly good movie to begin with! The only difference I could think of between Raimi's movies and this one, is the fact that Raimi's Spiderman's web was natural and he shot it from his wrists, while Webb's Spiderman uses cartridges to shoot his load (LOL)...other than that...pretty much nothing....just a bland and predictable movie...

title: Weak Story, Weak Spiderman, Why Reboot
review:
I am huge marvel fan but I think this is the weakest marvel movie I have seen in last 3-4 years. Movie is lacking passion and energy. Story is weak and Andrew Garfield was very cocky and weak. First of all let me start with some concrete statistics, I really don't understand why marvel has rebooted the series in first place, the original spider man (1,2, and 3) rank in first top 25 "All-Time USA Box office" list

12. Spider-Man (2002) $403,706,375

17. Spider-Man 2 (2004) $373,377,893

23. Spider-Man 3 (2007) $336,530,303

Looking at these numbers, all movies did well, and I don't see a problem continuing with same spider man and then further continue the series.

Talking about "Amazing Spider Man" story was very choppy and rushed, director has left a lot questions unanswered:

-What was the role of Indian actor Irfan Khan in the movie? Is he the villain in "ASM 2"? He left with the vial from the Oscorp building. What happened to it?

-Super hero's are meant to be stronger not weaker but all action in this movie was defense, no offense from spider man.

-Why spider man WEBS/WEBBING were coming out from electronic device in his arm? Why?, spider man based on the comic should have those coming out of hands.

-When the police officers got attacked by "THE LIZARD" and they were exposed to "REPTILE MIX GREEN GAS " all were supposed to become lizards  why they were not giving hard time to Spiderman when he was fighting "The Lizard / Dr. Curt Connors " in the end of the movie.

I think over all movie was disappointment from my point of view. I hope Webb can pull a better movie next time.

title: the eh...mazing spider-man
review: i gave this movie a chance and i will give it a five out of ten. not at all like the comics not even a little bit, the whole cross species experimentation threw me off, so pretty much every villain sounds like they are going to cross species some animal. what mysterio is going to have gold fish DNA thats why he wheres the fish bowl on his head. James Vanderbilt should be ashamed that he even wrote this atrocity. none of the movie made me chuckle or feel sad i was just﻿ like o man he dead. Sony you should be ashamed if you make a reboot do it right do not half the job put a hundred and ten percent into what you think will sell. why does peter have a skateboard he's suppose to be nerdy not a punk rocker. and peter parker also has that old camera with film in it yet he has a touch screen phone what is the reason behind that at least make him have a digital camera new day and age. i've been a spider-man fan all my life and i know witty comments that spider-man would say not some actor who mellows out all the comments. the movie did not make me move at the edge of my seat to see what happens next and the action scenes were to dulled out. when i watch action scenes i wanna feel like i am right there across the way seeing them fight but i felt like i was just in the movies watching a boring back and forth fight scene. what's the next one going to have Norman Osborn find a goblin from lord of the rings or some fantasy world to cross species with to make the green goblin, wow just wow not even a good wow

review:

title: Webb ftw!
review: This movie will probably surprise a lot of people who were obviously scorned by Spiderman 3. granted, this new take has nothing to do with the past series. at a pretty moderate pace, Spiderman doesn't dwell too long on the origin we alllll know too well but it does put a slightly more in-depth look at how things came to be. the story line is solid though there are times where it seems as if some scenes were skipped or rushed, the action needless to say was "amazing". very creative uses of web-slinging throughout and clear shots of the battles made for a great treat. its pretty clear why the sequel was already greenlit well before this even dropped. all should enjoy the ride, if not for the action itself then for the on-screen chemistry brought well by Stone and Garfield.

title: i liked the previous franchise more
review:
Tobey Maguire's Spider-man last came out in 2007.Just 5 years on and we have a reboot.The old franchise earned close to $2.5 billion from the 3 films.Now in 2012 we have Andrew Garfield's Spider-man.Even though the 3 films achieved a lot of commercial success,seeing movies like Avengers and Iron man earning a lot of money(about $1.5 billion for The Avengers) Sony decided to reboot the franchise.Why? Earning easy money most probably.Even though this is a reboot people are going to compare the 2 franchises.Well,Which of the franchise looks good? I will go with the former one though its still early considering the Amazing Spider-man is just 1 movie old.

Lets get to the story. Peter Parker(Andrew Garfield) lives with his aunt May(Sally Field) and uncle Ben(Martin Sheen).His parents had died mysteriously when he was a child.Peter is shown as a nerdy guy who is not really famous in school.He is often bullied at school at the behest of Flash Thompson.All this is similar to the previous franchise.One day in his basement Peter comes across his father's briefcase.He comes across a photograph which shows his father's then partner Curt Conners (Rhys Ifans).He gets to know that his father was researching on cross genetics at Oscorp.Wanting to learn more about his father he meets him.It is at Oscorp that he is bitten by a genetically modified spider that transforms him into Spider-man.Curt Conners has his own problems.He has lost one of his arms and Rajit Ratha(Irrfan Khan) is putting pressure on him to complete his research quickly.With the help of Parker he is able to perfect it but side effects take its toll on him transforming him into the lizard.Now it is up-to Spider-man to save the city from 'The Lizard'.

Gwen Stacy (Emma Stone) plays Parker's love interest in the film and I feel her character is well written as compared to Mary Jane in the previous films.Her father is the captain of the police and at times appears to be the second villain in the movie.

When I first got to know that Andrew Garfield and Emma Stone were going to be play the lead in this film I was quite excited. I liked Garfield as Eduardo Saverin in the highly acclaimed film 'The Social Network' and Emma Stone well, how could you not like her after so many good films she has done already.Andrew Garfield was good in this movie but I feel that his character as Peter Parker wasn't written well.His sudden transformation into Spider-man and well getting a hold of his powers was poorly written.The villain didn't have a strong presence in the film as Dr Octavious or say the Green Goblin (he isn't there till the interval in the film).I think his character could have been explored a lot more.Irrfan Khan marks the Indian presence in the film.Marc Webb said that he plays an important role in the film while Irrfan said that it is a really small role.Its up to the viewers to decide how good was his role.There are many changes that have taken place in the new Spider- man.Unlike the previous films here the Spider-man needs to make his own webs to swing around the city.This film has its own moments though.The scene in the subway is quite hilarious and the scene with Flash at the basketball court is quite funny as well.The action sequences are 'amazing'.The scene where Spider-man saves the child on the bridge is well written.The romance between Peter and Gwen for some would be the highlight of the film.The 3D effects tend to lower the value of this film.At times the movie appears to dark for our liking.

I am not saying this a bad film but the fact that the previous franchise had ended just 5 years back made you have higher expectations from the new one.I would prefer you watch this film in 2D.I would call this movie a one time watch.

PS if you do go on to watch this film, wait till the credits are rolled for the post credit scene which gives the hint about the possible villain of the sequel

My Rating 7.5/10

title: Not an amazing spiderman flick
review: This movie was not creative in terms of writing which I feel everyone was expecting of the Spiderman Franchise especially after the Spiderman 3 love story. There were loop holes in the plot and the director hasn't given enough time for the story to develop like e.g. All Peter parker had to do is take his fathers formula remember and give it to Connors and without verifying the formula in anyway Connors decides to put it in the system or even how Peter starts discovering his powers(Seriously in a train doing all that stupid stuff). How immature was that? More focus is on the high end animation and graphics which was truly amazing.Good break for Emma Stone as she was refreshingly good in the movie. Andrew Garfield looked lost all over the movie. Also I am still wondering in one scene why those lizards started going in the direction of Dr Connors experimental location.

title: Amazing is not enough to describe this mind blowing movie.
review: Actually this movie is much better than the previous ones (but i must admit spider-man 2 by Sam raimi is good). This time spidey is much agile and faster. It has everything..perfect swing effects and the depiction is really awesome. Parker and Gwen share a very good chemistry. It takes us to a new level of emotions, thrill, action..everything. Spidey's sense of humour is very good just like the comic one. Character Dr. Conners played by Rhy Ifans is quite ironic. He is a good man who made a wrong decision and attacks Peter many times. But, all goes well in the end. The swing and webbing shown at the end is awesome and we can hope for a sequel. I hope that you guys will like the movie very much. Guys go for it, its really awesome. I appreciate the work of Mark Webb. Its best to Watch it in 3d for amazing swing and action effects. And yes Andrew Garfield did a superb fab job.

title: A must watch
review:
When Columbia Pictures and Marvel Studios announced in 2010 that they were rebooting the Spiderman series with a new cast and crew, critics as well as the fans were skeptical whether a revamp to the commercially successful trilogy would actually work. But as it turns out 'The Amazing Spider-man' has had the highest opening for a Hollywood film in India, even surpassing the other Marvel Studios movie, 'The Avengers'.

So does the version of the Spiderman by Mark Webb match that of the director of the previous 3 movies by Sam Raimi? Yes it does, in fact better in certain cases.

Andrew Garfield astonishes us by a refreshingly original approach to the character of The Spider-man. For starters, he doesn't play the shy, nerdish guy which was played by Tobey Maguire. It was Garfield's childhood dream to play the Spider-man, and it clearly shows in the movie where he effortlessly shows us a more intriguing, interesting version of the superhero.

Emma Stone plays Gwen Stacy, the love interest of Peter Parker and not Mary Jane, unlike in the previous movies. She does a decent job, and the love affair between them is more appealing and less annoying, which was the case between Maguire and Dunst. There is a very sizzling chemistry between Emma and Garfield, the real life couple look great together on-screen as well. The first half of the story is almost the same as the original Spider- man of 2002, with more emphasis being given on the story of how Peter got separated from his parents. Peter learns Oscorp Labs hired his dad's former associate, Dr. Curt Connors, whom Peter hopes has knowledge about his parents. But Connors (Rhys Ifans) is doing strange things with science, developing a reptile serum to regrow his missing arm, and one of his steroidal spiders bites Peter. Connors later turn into a giant lizard with voice and mind of a man. But however, he is not a terrifying villain as in case of the earlier movies. Also there are not many mind -numbing fight sequences in the movie, however the excellent graphics and CGI make up for it. Irrfan Khan is a let down, who speaks with a strange accent in the 2-3 minutes of his screen time.

There are many funny scenes in the movie, like the one in which he falls on his knees and begs mercy from the thief, or the one in which he is lying upside down on the wall of his bedroom. The movie is a slight let down on the emotional front, as Raimi does a better job at handling the subject. All in all, the movie is definitely worth a watch. For all those who would rather download the movie on torrent and watch it, I would definitely suggest to have the theatrical experience of the movie. For all Marvel Comics fans, don't miss the cameo of Stan Lee, where he plays a librarian oblivious to the fight between Spider-Man and the Lizard happening behind him. And of course, typical of all Marvel movies, there is an after-credits scene, promising a sequel to the movie.

title: Decent enough...
review:
I had a chance to watch The Amazing Spider-Man today. It is a decent movie by all means, but I couldn't understand the decision by the studio to reboot the near perfect series about the same super hero.

Since, this is a review of the present film, I will stick to this movie and try not to compare this with the older one starring Tobey Maguire as Spider Man.

The movie depicts Spider-man as more human than a superhero. Peter Parker is just another kid, who's parents are missing since the time he remembers. He treats his guardians like dirt making the character believable. The scene where he starts playing the "Bounce" game on his mobile while waiting for the villain to appear is epic. Marc Webb, as the director hit goldmine with respect to the character building.

The villain is not believable though.

The visuals are very good. Again, Marc's insistence on not using the CGI for aerial shots of the Spider-Man in favor of using stunt men physically swinging worked wonders. The whole effort put in shows on the screen. 3D adds more depth to the visuals.

The final showdown between the Spider-Man and Lizard, however is the downside of the film. The whole story is predictable and after all this, at least the climax had to be extra-ordinary.

Over all, the movie is a decent fare, if seen in the 3D format. And watching Martin Sheen on screen was a treat.

title: Have a different feeling ...
review: This is my first review in IMDb.I went for this one today with little expectations mainly due to the change in cast as Garfield replaces Tobey.The main thing to be mentioned here is that this is a reboot of the Spiderman series.But changing all my doubts this one came out to be a great movie.This one had a change in its feeling.Spidey is more open now...the entirely different attitude of spidey made this fresh to watch.More of a comic book oriented story.There is more emotional content in here.Emma as Gwen is more real and smart.3D has its effects on certain scenes and was good.It is really a good entertainer which will give you a fresh feeling.

title: Makes the previous outings looks like Batman Returns, Batman Forever and Batman & Robin respectively
review:
I wasn't expecting much from this movie based on the previous three Spider-man movies. I had been hoping for a reboot of the franchise ever since I had seen the first Spider-Man movie 10 years earlier.

This movie gives us a Spider-Man that's much more true to the original comics. I wasn't at all surprised when Tobey Maguire's Spider-Man wasn't considered for inclusion in The Avengers. The previous three movies did nothing to boost his career, but I can expect to see a lot more from Andrew Garfield in the coming years and I would love to see him in the sequel to The Avengers. Emma Stone also manages to outshine Kirsten 'Dunce' as the love interest, but in all fairness, that's not terribly difficult for such a sub-par actress like Kirsten.

Even if this story had been done before, it certainly hadn't been given the respectful treatment that it had in this film. The 3D is this movie could hardly have been done any better. The common denominator in all the bad reviews, besides the fact that they were apparently written by 12 year-olds (seriously, read some of them) is that people simply didn't like the villain, therefore they complain about the CGI to try to give themselves credibility.

This is on track to be the movie of the year and not The Avengers.

title: best spider man movie since spider-man 2!
review: wow it was a great movie. i mean a 7.8 should definitely should not be the rating but rather a 9. it was awesome and i was emotionally into this movie! Andrew was a great actor, and Emma stone was a great Gwen. overall this movie was amazing fitting its title! i loved it it was not to complicated so kids will follow it very well and also the characters had very good depth and you could relate to them a great movie overall. so see it it was awesome. i loved this movie. there was a good amount of action but not to the point to where it was unbearable and the CGI was amazing not to mention the actors, they were very good as well. so go see this movie seriously it is almost as good as the avengers. i have hope in Marc Webb what a great movie.

title: There is life after Raimi
review:
