As for Andrew Garfield, I get it, I get that he lacked conviction, but hey, kids now days are so morally ambiguous, it was actually pretty convincing that Spidey would in fact retain a bit of a flawed compass when it comes to right/wrong.

All in all, The Amazing Spider-Man is a beautifully shot and acted film, especially when dramatic scenes take center stage. Some of its logic not so much, it's choice in angles with the Lizard not so much, its 3D capabilities not so much (it was pretty flat in my REAL-D theater), but if anything, its worth seeing for the rare experience noted earlier. However, if I was to sum up the amount of decent reboots and remakes in recent years, in the least I would call them interesting if nothing else. Thus, I left the theater asking myself, how long can I keep this up with these re-hashes? How long until interesting ceases to be and becomes just plain insulting?

title: Amazing? Definitely!!
review:
so, I saw The Amazing Spider-Man today, needless to say.. I gotta give my review on it.. For starters, I loved it. What we have in this movie is the mix of the 4 core Spider-Man comic titles, which are Peter Parker / Spider-Man, The Amazing Spider-Man, Web of Spider-Man and The Spectacular Spider-Man. For those that are NOT avid Spidey fans, let me explain. Peter Parker / Spider-Man comics was the series that dealt with more of Pete's personal life, The Amazing Spider-Man was were all the characters came together in a big mixing pot, Web of Spider-Man was where all the dark, nitty gritty happened and Spectacular Spider-Man is where all the action on Pete's personal level happened. That being said, ITS ALL in this movie. The movie feels like Web of Spider-Man, has the resolve of Amazing, the action and battle of Spectacular, and the personal story, straight from peter parker / Spider-Man Now, we all know that Spidey's story is and has always been about love for family, friends and the people he cares for.. Its all here in this movie. Andrew does a PHENOMAL job playing Pete and even resembles peter parker from the cover of amazing spider-man vol. 2 #37! Emma Stone as Gwen Stacy is AMAZING. nobody could have done a better job. She was PERFECT in every way, and her chemistry with Andrew is CRAZY! i can definitely see them working on more films together. (and I must admit, I may have dropped a few tears for them ) Rhys Ifans as Curt Conners / The Lizard was excellent as well. I really felt that he did his homework for the part, as he brought the character to life straight from the comics. (and yes, we get to see Lizard with his Labcoat :) ) Aunt May (Sally Field) and Martin Sheen (Uncle Ben) also brought more to their characters as well. (although aunt may's look seemed a little out of touch without her grey hair lol) Captain Stacy (Dennis Leary) has his due too! The entire movie from beginning to end keeps a great steady pace, and does NOT go overboard at the climax of the film but keeps you on the edge of your seat (just like spectacular comics) From the previews you've seen, we get to see Pete's parents, and yes even little petey in a flashback intro to the movie which leads up to a scene where while helping uncle ben in the basement, he comes across an old briefcase that used to belong to his dad...needless to say, he begins to investigate that ends up leading him to Curt Conners in an Oscorp lab. Spider-Man's origin, is untouched pretty much, (still bitten by a spider in a lab) Hilarity ensues upon discovery of his new abilities, and rest assured, the wise-cracking spidey IS in this movie, a lot! unlike the previous 3 spidey films, we get to see a vulnerable spidey, which in the past films he just seemed to "shrug" his hits and bruises off. Although not completely the same, but from this point on you get a feeling of the "Death & Destiny" story from the comics. The special effects are top notch! and I'm sure every pose you have ever seen Spider-Man do, IS IN THIS MOVIE!! From web slinging, to jumping, to diving, to flipping and catapulting! not only that, but when he shoots a web, you can see him push his arm forward as if he was "casting" a fishing line to give his web that extra push. You can see the webbing wobble as its shot, and you can actually FEEL the strength of his webbing just by looking at it. There's SO much more I want to say, but I have to let you all see it with your own eyes. As much as I love the previous trilogy (yes even the 3rd movie, lol) This movie made me realize how too big and bulky, sometimes clumsy feeling Tobey Maguire was as Peter.

I still hate the new suit though. haha

I highly recommend this movie to you all, including those that are big fans of Spider-man.

I give this movie a solid 4.5 out of 5 stars.

In closing, I hope that when and If you do see this film, you will enjoy it as much as I have.

title: Quite Close To Amazing!
review:
Well So After Some Expectation of this and getting mixed reviews about it, I finally watched The Amazing Spiderman today and here's what I Thought about it. Entertaining, Well Acted and Smartly Directed with Good action and Very good Visual Effects, along with a dazzling Emma Stone and a Cool Spidey, this movie is bound to entertain audience and its a very good start to this new reboot of the series, and it has everything in it starting from Action to Acting to Visual Effects and Storyline which is mostly due to the hard work of Director Mark Webb and also due to great efforts from the leading actors.

The Story of this movie is probably known by any comic book/superhero fan but this is a whole new start to the Spiderman franchise and the film-makers have made quite a few drastic but effective changes in this movie which can make it better than its previous one. So it again shows how Peter Parker(Now played by Andrew Garfield) becomes Spider-man and also develop a crush for Gwen Stacy(Emma Stone) along with showing us some of his cool moves and also defeating the dangerous Lizard/Curt Connors( Rhys Ifans) in the way to save New York City.

The Acting by the leading actors are quite effectively good and the new Spidey aka Andrew Garfield has done a marvelous job in portraying Spider-man, And i personally love this Spider-Man more than Toby's Spiderman. Garfield has played this Super-hero very cool-ly and has done his everything to entertain audience right from when he becomes Spider- man and I think He's surely gonna become a fan-favourite for this. Emma Stone was Dazzling as Gwen Stacy and played the love-life of Peter Parker Brilliantly with her charismatic and good acting and she surely does justice to this character and I really loved her in this role. Rhys Ifans is quite a brilliant actor and he again does very well in this movie as Curt Connors/Lizard and he does both the positive and negative part of this character brilliantly.

Director Mark Webb who incidentally himself has the title ''Webb'' has done an excellent job with the start of this new series and has set the right tone for this new super-hero franchise. He Did Brilliantly with all aspects of this film starting from Acting to Visual Effects also convincingly telling the story to the audience and the movie always has some entertainment in it so that it does'nt bore the audience. He has made a really good super-hero film and not those drab only action one's. Well Done to him and I expect good things from him in the future.

The Visual Effects of this movie is'nt as good as The Avengers but its still very good and the effects of Spidey Flying around and jumping through the streets of New York city sometimes are really fascinating and really breathtaking at times, so I guess the Visual effects team deserve some credits for putting all their hard-work into this movie. I Thought the Editing was a bit bad and some parts of the movie would have been better not showed.

The Story of this movie has a all new kind of a tone to it than the Last Spider-Man and this also has some new characters to it and that makes it more interesting, and this story of Spiderman vs Lizard was shown on the screen quite well by the director and I hope that the next part will be better if not as good as this.

This is not exactly ''Amazing'' buts its quite close to it, And with the cool Garfield as Spider-Man and A Good Villain along with the dazzling Emma Stone, this one will definitely entertain all kind of movie lovers and specially comic books fan should also go for this one, Because i liked it very much.

My Rating: 7.5/10

title: Good Attempt , The Amazing Spiderman does deserve a watch
review:
If the Sam Raimi's Version of Spiderman is still fresh in your memory , There is a very good chance that the reboot will appear appear boringly familiar .This is after all the origin story all over again - Peter Parker gets bitten, he discovers his 'spider powers', he uses them first on the school bully, then goes out in the street to fight crime, finally clashing with a fearsome villain while cops and New Yorkers look on in amazement.

To be fair, despite covering pretty much the same ground as that earlier film, The Amazing Spider-Man still works. You could put it down to the emotional depth that (500) Days of Summer director Marc Webb brings to key scenes, or simply to leading man Andrew Garfield's refreshingly original approach to the part

A solid actor, blessed with oodles of charisma and unmistakable presence, Garfield pitches Peter Parker as a brooding introvert who prefers the company of his skateboard to actual friends . This new film unfolds Parker's world with more attitude. The feel-good mush of the last three films is gone, and the action is duly sexed up to suit 3D basics .Even in the scenes which resemble those of the previous versions , Andrew Garfield delivers a solid performance , So it was truly refreshing to watch a better more competent actor play the Role of Spiderman.

Peter Parker's love interest in the film Gwen Stacey played by Emma Stone who is sexy and intelligent appears more appealing and less annoying than Kirsten Dunst . Here Gwen appears a bold decisive person willing to risk her life for Spiderman unlike Mary Jane who was portrayed as a spineless damsel in distress and an emotional fool who kept bouncing from one person to another not realizing who she loved actually.

Though this film does focus a lot on the romance between the lead characters for most of the film ,Which I feel could have been reduced significantly , Its important to note that the sizzling chemistry is in a way important . It could be an attempt by the Director to show the grief that pain and the grief that Spiderman would face when he decides to kill off Gwen's character in the subsequent sequels. The biggest highlight of the film is the terrace kiss where Peter Parker drags Gwen Stacy close to him through his web shooter as she appears totally stunned before the kiss . This was way better than the upside down kiss in Spiderman where Kirsten appeared in a soaking red dress.

What works in the film is the manner which the scenes are shot right from the the subway scene to the scene where Spiderman saves the kid from a burning car or even the scene where Spiderman swings right across the city to Oscorp Towers . The scenes are appear spectacular in the 3d format

This film appears to be a realistic take on Spiderman . The concept of webshooters and the spidey suit are definitely more believable (I would have liked to see Spiderman running out of web though)

Spidermans swinging moments also appear far more realistic than the perfect web flights taken by Tobey in the previous versions.

Where the film however does not work was the portion where a huge time was spent on focussing on the mysterious disappearance of his parents which does not have any relation to the outcome of this film (Highly unlikely that it will have any relation to the sequels),The unconvincing manner which Uncle Ben was shot and choosing the Lizard as Spidermans Primary Foe. What really disappoints is that Spiderman is not able to track down the person who shot Uncle Ben .The iconic line'With Great Power comes Great Responsibility' appears no-where in the film. I do feel let down by the fact that I had really high expectations watching the trailer but was left wanting on account of the not so great script.

The Amazing Spiderman is definitely more dark and edgy as compared to the previous versions . I would however want the Director to play an act of balancing the film with lighter moments of comedy and wise one line cracks. The directors should make more use of Andrew Garfields fine acting skills and also focus more on showing Peter Parker's intelligence and adeptness .

Make sure that you stay till the end of the credits to watch the extra scene. I hope that the Next Spiderman Sequel holds more promise to give films like the Batman Series or the next sequel to the Avengers a run for their money.

title: I could not make it through this awful film.
review:
I didn't care much for the previous Spider-Man films because they were too cartoonish and silly. This is the complete opposite but even worse. This film is so drab and boring I couldn't finish it.

Truly an amazing piece of crap.

The actor that plays Spider-Man is one ugly dude. He is also very unlikable.

This is the worst film I have seen in a while. Do kids actually like a film like this?

To me, this movie is just unwatchable. If you are a thinking person, avoid this film.

title: Forced
review: The casting was off. A 45 looking 30 year old to play a high school student? The entire film lacked heart. There was no chemistry between the actors. I enjoyed the new story line of trying to find what happened to Peter's parents, unfortunately this pursuit is abandoned halfway through the film. Disappointing performances, lackluster film.

title: Inconsistent, charmless, awkward and far too downbeat. Clearly none of the dozen writers discussed what this should be.
review:
Pretty much every review has rehashed the same old crap about how this is too soon after the old trilogy and oh isn't it ironic the name of the guy directing this movie so I'll keep it brief because there's not much to say about this film. I enjoyed the first two movies with Maguire (and looking back, the first one is real cheesy) but this one is far too downbeat and lacks all the charm any blockbuster could've had to make it enjoyable. Peter Parker ends up being a douchebag and every scene is awkward and contrived. It's a complete hit and miss film but the hits are okay (fortunately towards the end with obvious Terminator 2 references) and the misses are big due to none of the dozen writers of this film talking to each other about what they were writing. I liked Martin Sheen, Denis Leary and Rhys Ifans but I felt Emma Stone and Andrew Garfield missed the mark. Marc Webb was the wrong director for this.

4/10

title: This movie felt like it missing half the story!
review:
As I saw Spider-man 3 not that long ago, that was still fresh in my mind, I still found this movie to early for a -Re-boot of the series.

I didn't really like how this movie flowed, I think they could have done better Job of him discovering is powers, Instead of over the top Train scenes.

I don't know if was meant to funny or not but I found that way to Silly and I didn't the fact that most of time,

I didn't like the fact in had the mask off most of time and I didn't like how he got used to his powers so fast, I felt that the movie moved to fast, I didn't really care of Parker in this movie

In the other series, I felt that Connect to Parker and felt that was lot more Developed and i found more Like-able then this one.

The action scenes were good and fun watching but I found this movie focused way too much on Action instead of everything else.

I didn't like the ending at all, it found really bland.

I got some good thinks to say about this is that the acting this movie was really good from the whole cast and effect were really good in this movie as well.

6/10

title: Continuing Spider-Man
review:
Spectacular! That is one way to describe this film as it not only expresses the action and adventure of a teenage superhero, but also the life of being a teenager.

This film captures both those aspects better than the Tobey Maguire Spider-man films. With Tobey, I always felt that the spider-man films had a strong adult present when the super-hero was in fact JUST finishing high school.

Every actor in this film was very important to the way the story moved as they would show conflict, bravery, fright, and courage.

From the actors to the directors of this film, I thank all of them for creating such an amazing experience, never, to be forgotten.

title: A Good Way to Kill time...
review:
Well, to begin with, the movie wasn't all i had anticipated it to be, which was, something better than what i had seen.

The movie starts out quite brilliantly, and follows up with an awesome story, but its has to be the lack of Spidey humor that i felt was most lacking, as we all know, spider man is the wise crack of the world of marvel, and well this was , a bit too... Serious. They missed out on the spidey sense bit, the story gets quite dry in the middle, and quite draggy at that. Definitely not a movie i'd want to end up watching alone. Worth one watch though, hopefully the sequel should prove to be better..

title: Secrets WON'T be revealed.
review:
PROS:

+ good cast (though I didn't love him in it Garfield was good in the role, he emoted well. As someone who finds Stone annoying I didn't find that to be the case here. Martin Sheen is a standout despite the small part)

+ Denis Leary's shotgun moment

+ solid special effects

+ to my memory the best Stan Lee cameo to date

CONS:

  • hit and mostly miss script (the great Rhys Ifans is decent but he really doesn't have much to work with and because of that his character and the villain are a bit weak, and the same can be said for Denis Leary though he does have a cool moment at one point as mentioned in the 'pros'. The movie is also very, very much a remake of Raimi's original film which really surprised and disappointed me. I liked the original movie quite a bit, but based on the marketing and promotion for this movie they were telling us this would be going in a different direction, yet besides more scenes at night there really wasn't that much different and actually a lot of awkward note-for-note similarities almost to the point of the Psycho remake. I mean hell even though it's a different villain Ifans' Lizard still battles the evil, over the top voices in his head just like Dafoe's Goblin, though it's not as well done as with most of the similarities to the original. Annoying plot holes, occurrences and character choices also plague the script, like where all the tiny lizards came from or what happened to mouse-lizard or why the Police Captain went to the top of the tower all by himself... and finally, Peter Parker. For the most part he's a likable character--up until the very end at least where his choice makes him such a despicable, unlikable and selfish character)


  • art design (I wasn't a fan of the look of The Lizard or of Spidey's suit)


  • music (the score wasn't bad by any means, and actually pretty solid in general but in terms of a superhero score and in terms of the theme in comparison to the previous Spider-Man theme... it doesn't hold a candle)


  • while Marc Webb does surprisingly well considering what he came from before I can't say that any of the action sequences were particularly thrilling or memorable. 95% of the action also takes place in the middle of the night, which just doesn't feel right for Spider-Man. Also the only real memorable action sequence (and it is a pretty cool one) isn't even in the movie, and that would be the POV sequence we've seen in promotional material. Only about 5 seconds of that sequence makes it into the final cut of the movie, which was surprising and confusing.


  • deceiving (the marketing campaign was built all around the 'secrets' of Parker's parents being revealed as well as lines like 'do you have any idea what you really are Peter?' and 'if you want to know the truth about your parents Peter, come and get it'... well none of those lines are actually in the movie and neither are the plot points or revelations that would come with them. We literally get none of that other than a post-credits scenes that hints that we'll actually get what was advertised for this movie... in the sequel)


OVERALL:

I was hoping, and actually kind of expecting, that it would surprise me as I really couldn't get that excited for it initially yet heard the good word (even from a family member). Unfortunately it did the opposite and actually disappointed me. It's not a bad movie, but it is a flawed one and most of the things that it does right are just damn near the exact same things we've already seen, making it a bit tedious and having me just want to fast-forward the movie at times which is never a good feeling. I was open to it, but it disappointed me. Still I think I'd give a sequel a chance at least, if we even get there that is, as the only thing truly amazing about this Spider-Man flick was the budget, a whopping $220 million that you just really, really don't see on the screen.

title: Just above average spider man
review: You would think someone named Mark Webb would be a shoe in to direct a movie version of Spider man with that name. You would also think a movie entitled the amazing spider man would be in in fact an amazing take on the material. On both of these accounts you'd be wrong. Not to say the film doesn't have moments and is generally entertaining but for the most part it's kind of a mess. This time around the take on Peter Parker is a more realistic one. He's a little annoying, a little selfish, a lot more sarcastic so your normal teenager. The events in the film transpire accordingly with the bite of the spider and the death of his parents and than Uncle. But the film unravels in an interesting way making the material seem fresh and mostly unvisited. What the film gets wrong mostly lies in it's direction. Despite a few stabs at the darker side of things this seems like spidey light. It's very comical, with lots of jokes and a sort of disneyish generic atmosphere. Which is all fine and dandy but the film just doesn't mesh well. It moves sloppily back and forth beneath genres and subplots without building a realistic engagement to the events depicted. The good lies in the films interesting and inspired casting choices Andrew Garfield is geekyily gorgeous in the lead and although his character is somewhat angsty he manages to make him likable and is truly gifted at being emotionally resonant. Emma Stone is cute but unnecessary as his love interest and even though the 2 share winning chemistry their relationship isn't allowed time to develop appropriately and seems a little forced. Sally Field also adds some solid support as Aunt May. The film sports nice special effects but the 3D is just so so. A better take on the material would have been a darker one such as as the dark knight is to Batman franchise. I do think they made the right decision in rebooting the material as the last installment in the previous franchise had worn out it's welcome. As Spider Man films go this one falls into being the second best. However, it should be noted that although I enjoyed the original film immensely I wasn't a big fan of the others. There's a lot to enjoy here and I would welcome another installment but I do hope Marc Webb is not a part of it as well as the screenwriters that penned this installment. Although a piece of passable Hollywood blockbuster entertainment the film admirably works better on it's human levels which is a great feat to accomplish. That being said the film ends up being a just above average spider man than an amazing one.

title: Watch only in 3D for visual treat- "Not Amazing"
review:
Movie is quite refreshing and worth watching.

It's good to see Peter young and more as a boy.

Almost 50min has been dedicated to what it is already known to viewers.

This was done to bring in a new series of Spider man.

Viewers were made to wait for jaw dropping action sequences.

Chemistry between Emma and Garfield is good and more pleasing to watch them.

The Lizard looks quite funny rather intimidating.

There is no interesting plot which makes a viewer stick to his seat.

Just wait and watch fantastic action sequences in 3D only else waste of time and energy.

title: Nothing amazing in The Amazing Spider-Man, blame it on the script
review:
Mr. Director ! You are such a noob and you have proved it very well. Who in the world would make a movie with such ludicrous script? When you are creating a movie, a Super-hero movie, then you should very well keep in mind that there are others as Iron Man, Bat Man and The Avengers against whom you have to stand. Every thing needs to be fantabulous. No flaws. And this is what you came up with.

The most distinguishing difference between Sam Raimi, the director of earlier Spider-man movies and Marc Webb, director of the new one is that the later one is fresh out of college of direction and has a lot to areas to work upon. Sam Raimi has proved a lot by offering a wide range of genre of cinema. And that's exactly why a monstrous challenge for Webb grew up. The Amazing Spider-Man was a great onus that was put on, let's say, an immature shoulders of Webb and there's where everything falters. In the world where we have Nolan and Joss Whedon, this guy did not find a perfect spot even to stand up.

Let's talk about the movie. All characters played there parts very well. A great justice to all the characters has been done. No one could be a better choice than Garfield for the lead role. Garfield is intense, smart and a genuine charm he carries with himself. Simply flawless. He brings a perfectionist's touch to the Spider-man's character. The girl, Emma Stone, has done an outstanding work. I have always adored her. I was never fond of Mary Jane who would always cry and carry a rather shabby personality. The then Peter-Jane love story was all just stupid. Here is a brand new genial love story with a girl you'd always dream of. She is smart, sassy and a perfect fit for Mr. Parker. Other characters - Parker's uncle, his aunt, the doctor and the girl's father, everyone did well.

The direction was not that great and the poor script extinguished all the fire the director thought of putting in the movie. The movie were meant to be grand one considering its superb characterization and some breath-taking effects but the script ruined it all. The expectations from this movie were bit higher. Spider-man 4 was scrapped because Raimi could not find a great plot. Five years' wait and we thought we would get some great kicks but sadly nothing much was dished out.

Watch the movie for the effects and the fresh new characters. Do not expect anything extraordinary otherwise you will end up disappointing yourself as I did.

title: Though entertaining and going hit in theaters, Amazing Spiderman doesn't quite live up to people's expectation for more fun and excitement. http://bit.ly/KK1QuK
review:
The Amazing Spiderman AMS starts from the childhood of Peter parker when his parents left him to Uncle Ben's house due to some unresolved issues with the science work he does in cross species genetics. And Peter parker of 19 years in science college, encounters something accidentally (afraid of spoilers!) when he reaches the Company OSCORP where his father Richard Parker and Dr Curt Connors worked to find the whereabout of his parents and the reason they left him. Human and Spider cross species (later calling himself as Spiderman) starts taking the work of Man in badge with his spider skills. The story turns into a super action fight between Spiderman and giant Lizard after another cross species genetic accident in OSCORP turning the author of "World without pain" into the giant devious Lizard. The movie has different angle in developing a new Spiderman than it has in the Sam Raimi's Spider-Man (2002). Though the Original Comic Hero's Character to save People from crime and evil is same, AMS has more of the genetics and the science in the new Series start.

Indian actor Irfan Khan in his very short role speaks less and leaves no significant presence there and I forecast him as a Villainous Comic Character in coming Part of this Spiderman series.

Some emotional scenes like the death of Uncle Ben, payback of a father to save Spiderman- lifesaver of his son, and the promise from Peter to NYPD captain in his dying stage puts you in tears. And the closeup of swinging action enthralls you in a different way than the previous series did. Also the last minute clip after the end of movie crew and casts name showing Dr. Connors and another person in jail, makes you curious about the next Spiderman movie Amazing Spiderman 2 to be released in 2014.

The Return of another start of web swinging is not enough to stand out in the war of superheroes and the Skinny Spiderman that speaks while flying Character build up has not done much to wipe out Tobby Maguire Spiderman image from your head. So, the Reboot of the Spiderman Series with Webb as the director (may be that's the reason behind the reboot...laughs!!!), does not live up with people's expectation for the new series to be more exciting and fun though QFX was full- packed with people to watch their favorite superhero in 3D.

http://rdulal.blogspot.com/2012/06/amazing-spider-man-review.html

title: movie was decent
review: I really appreciated the work done with this. All of the graphic enhancements are very nice. It's better than the originals with Sam Raimi, but I think there could have been a more intricate plot with better characters. Andrew Garfield and Emma Stone did well, Denis Leary was very Denis Leary-esque. So, not sure how I feel about that. Rhys Ifans was stellar, but let that go rather quickly. Martin Sheen was great for the short time he was in it, Sally Field was very reserved. I guess Aunt May always was though. I wish Peter Parkers' parents had greater roles. However, still hard for me to keep my eyes open. I was out about 90 mins in, I woke up at the climactic parts and still couldn't hang, just not fascinating enough. For me, overall lacking in "suspension of disbelief" for Marvel, I had more fun in Avengers. I once again woke up for the end and was not thrilled. Please, someone, let me know if I am being too quick to judge.

title: A dive into Peter Parker's emotional paradigm.
review:
A proper portrayal of a Spiderman who belongs to the 2010+ age.

The movie was quite magnetic all through the way but somewhere down the line, the creative context of the plot didn't quite meet to some "wow" making ends. The emotionally confused Peter Parker was portrayed at its finest by Andrew Garfield. The romantic and emotional build ups between Emma Stone's Gwen Stacy and Peter Parker was one of the most interesting parts in the film besides the action and the visual effects.

Talking of the action, it was perfect, agile and collective like the Spiderman would have actually had and then came along The Lizard (Dr. Curt Connors' alter ego) played by Rhys Ifans which somewhat didn't convince much on the animation's point of view and also the character design went loose.

Overall the movie was entertaining but not so competent a reboot if you would consider the plot.

title: The Best Spider-Man Movie Ever
review: Watched The Amazing Spider-Man with Andrew Garfield(The Social Network) as Peter Parker/Spider-man, The Lovely Emma Stone(Easy A) as Gwen Stacy ,Martin Sheen(The Departed) as Ben Parker,Sally Field (Homeword Bound:The Incredible Journey) as Aunt May ,Chris Zylka(Shark Night 3D) as Flash Thompson, Denis Leary(Ice Age) as George Stacy ,Irrfan Khan (Slumdog Millionaire) as Doctor Ratha, and Rhys Ifans(Harry Potter And The Deathly Hollows) as Doctor Curt Connors/The Lizard. I Really Enjoyed The Film Also This how Spider-Man is supposed to be also enjoyed that he cracked Jokes also enjoyed the complexity of his character glad they showed how he became our friendly neighborhood Spider-man also Ifans played a fantastic curt Connors also I was very empathic towards him seeing as he wanted to cure himself also loved Stones Gwen Stacy she was funny and not your typical girl next door, .Great Music By James Horner(Avatar), Cinematography By John Schwartzman(National Treasure:Book Of Secrets) , Costume Design By Kym Barrett(Sleepy Hollow) and Direction By Marc Webb(500 Days Of Summer) The Best Spider-Man Movie Ever 8/10

title: The most suitable word I have for this movie would be 'filler'. Were I Madonna, I'd have said 'Reductive'.
review:
Plot: A young boy Peter Parker realizes his life would never be the same after his parent's sudden departure; he is raised by his uncle and aunt who are fully supportive and caring but never mention about Parker's past. When Peter learns about his father's research, he seeks Dr. Curt Connors, his father's research partner who is now experimenting with genetics to find a cure to many fatal ailments. The inquisitive nature of Parker leads to his transformation as Spiderman, after being bitten by a rare spider. His newly acquired powers overwhelm him at first but he somehow brings it under control and gains a formidable reputation in college. After his uncle's death, Parker sets out to find the killer and in the process captures many wanted criminals well before the police does. This irks Police Chief Stacy who labels him a public menace and doesn't hold a good opinion about Peter Parker (who's now Chief Stacy's daughter Gwen's boyfriend) as well. On the other side, a disastrous self-experiment turns Dr Curt Connors into a monstrous reptile that unleashes terror in the city and only Spiderman can bring an end to this unwanted menace.

After some memorable moments and some not very appetizing ones, could we ride once again with Toby McGuire donning the red suit or would Spiderman have to call it off forever? Mark Webb has an answer for us, a reboot that has certain benefits but also raises many questions: Did this truer comic book interpretation of Spiderman really transcend to the silver screen? By giving Spidey and the other characters edgier but more caricatural personas, will the franchise really continue? Why does Peter Parker's hidden identity have to be so blatantly obvious? What's the difference between this Peter Parker who does astonishing feats at college and yet gets away, and Miley Stewart who dons a golden wig and no one recognizes her even though her father is Billy Ray Cyrus?

In Amazing Spiderman, a major difference in the cast is the absence of Mary Jane, who had become one of Spiderman's most recognizable faces. We instead have Gwen Stacy, the blonde whom we got a peek of in Spiderman 3, as Peter Parker's love interest. However, Gwen does not sit cozily in the background while Spidey is battling and neither does she sulk much unlike MJ. She throws in some punches and kicks, urges Spiderman to beat them all up and is more thoughtful. It can be hard to accept this spunky, courageous Gwen because we are so used to the lady in distress act. But she may grow on us just like the fearless Elena or Chloe from Uncharted series. Spiderman is played by Andrew Garfield, who isn't a typical geek that Toby managed to be; he is a cool geek, or just a normal college guy with great scientific knowledge but poor physique. Therefore he didn't really take time to win over us with his charisma as Spiderman even though I didn't root for him as much as I did for Toby when he halted the derailed train. Toby's shy and quiet Spidey had a charm of his own in a way we take his character's well-being seriously; Garfield's Spidey meanwhile entertains us more but we find it harder to sympathize with him though I must say Garfield did nail that scene where he confronted his uncle about his father. By the way, all those who have seen the Indian film Three Idiots may notice a similarity between Andrew Garfield and Indian actor Sharman Joshi's style of acting.

What also played a major role in deciding the previous Spiderman movies' success or failure was the potential of the nemesis; while Green goblin didn't wield much excitement because of the sketchy latter part of the first film, Doc Oc made us tremble at his stature as well as pity his tragic story in Spiderman 2, while Green Goblin's son, Sandman and Venom were potent enough in the third installment but the film itself was enfeebled by the dull love triangle. Rhys Ifans acts well, however his character isn't exactly memorable in any way; in Batman the most feared villains are Joker, Harley Quinn, Mr. Freeze, Poison Ivy, Scarecrow, Two Face but who really cares for Bane though his strength is equally formidable? Maybe Ifans couldn't play his character better, but what really made his character weak was the character itself. My mind went "A reptile as the main villain – are you kidding me?" and sadly it felt the same way throughout.

Spiderman feels like a filmed comic book, which is generally flipped through casually without getting involved with the emotional aspect of the story to a greater extent. If you look the movie this way, you'll say it's the best of the series. People buy dozens of Archie comics and read it in the same perfunctory manner. But many people who love movies find that the factor that etches a film in our minds for a long time is a moment of tension. This tension happens only when we are deeply involved in a film and for that to happen, the movie has to make the audience realize the protagonist's dilemma and want him/her to overcome it. And this cannot and does not happen in such a breezy, comic book-like adaptation.

Amazing Spiderman will surely get support from Beyblade-crazy children and teenagers who love saying the word 'awesome!' – It will be one of the top grossing films of 2012. But I personally think 230 million dollars are unnecessary for a movie that looks no different from the Spiderman and Beyblade cartoons that come on the television. The most suitable word that strikes me for the film after writing this review is 'filler'.

My Rating: The sole number that came in my mind after leaving the theater was 5.5 out of 10.

title: Spiderman with a web-ful of personality and spfx.
review:
I know there are some issues concerning this reboot coming out so close to Sam Rami's trilogy, so I'll give my hopefully unbiased two cents on that first. Perhaps the time interval didn't call for a re-boot, but I think the overall story did. The re-boot has a vastly different feel to it than the films of the early 2000's with Tobey Maguire. This is really Spiderman for a different audience, so be prepared to hate one or the other. I think the reboot did a better job with making Peter more relatable and easier to root for, acting and scripting, character writing, and general plausibility. The older versions had a more cohesive story and established Spiderman more as a hero than as a person. I personally think that TASM came out better overall, though I haven't seen the '04 and '07 installments, but the perception of which is better seems to be a matter of taste more than anything else.

Peter Parker, while somewhat reserved, is portrayed as likable and emotional. He's a very active protagonist: everything extraordinary that he does is a result of his own actions. He makes his own web-slingers and suit and actively initiates and pursues a positive relationship with Gwen Stacy. Even the pivotal radioactive spider bite is only possible because of his scientific curiosity and his quest to discover his past. Peter is driven equally by his emotions and morals, as we see from start to end that he is willing to do good, but is blinded by emotion in the scene of Uncle Ben's death and his quest of vengeance against his murderer. Gwen is also a very prominent figure who is important in both sides of Peter's life through her complex relationship with him, her position at Oscorp, and her being the police captain's daughter. The irritable Captain Stacy is an antagonist through his hunt for Spiderman, but he's not a really a villain since you can sympathize with him. The real villain is Dr. Conners/The Lizard, who has some interesting motives that we get a good look at. At first, we're on his side, but when he takes his desire to expunge weakness too far, he becomes a literal and figurative monstrosity. Some of his scenes as the Lizard felt a little clichéd with his taunting dialogue and roaring, both of which seemed out of character. Aunt May and Uncle Ben show up occasionally, mostly to emphasize the difficulty Peter has in balancing his life. Uncle Ben's death comes in a very valiant fashion, and I absolutely loved the new version of the "with great power comes great responsibility" quote. It's not as memorable, but I think it's a lot better in inspiring greatness in Peter and the audience.

The story begins with Peter searching for his father, which leads him to Oscorp. Eventually this story line just sort of dissipates, which could be a problem for a lot of people, but incorporating it into the rest of the story wouldn't have felt quite right either. The same happens with Peter's search for Uncle Ben's killer. It starts off as a strong motive for Peter and his gradual transformation into Spiderman, but then he just suddenly stops looking for the man without explanation. The bulk of the story involves the classic superhero/super villain face-off, though we do get to see a lot of the villain's side of the story. Of course, there's also the internal conflict of Peter and Gwen's relationship and how it is challenged by Captain Stacy and Gwen's own courage.

The execution was excellent on almost every level. The dialogue was motivated and realistic, but the script lacked in some of the high-school scenes that felt pretty old- fashioned. Fortunately there weren't too many of those scenes, but I would sign the screenwriter up for a crime comedy over Breakfast Club reboot. The acting was nice with lots of personality and some incredible chemistry between Andrew Garfield and Emma Stone. The special effects were very stylized and resulted in some very cool action sequences. Some of the CGI didn't look stunningly realistic, but we don't exactly love superhero movies for their realism. James Horner contributed an awesome main theme that he uses throughout.

If you were disappointed in 2000's movies, then I would definitely give this a try. One thing to be wary of in your decision to watch it is the trailer. Much of it gives you a good foretaste, but DO NOT hinge your hopes on any of lines from the trailer because most of them are not included in the final product. That's actually a good rule to follow when watching any trailer since there are lots of tricks the editors can use to fool you into thinking there is a whole conversation taking place that is not in the movie at all. If you're skeptical, watch until Conners first becomes the Lizard and then decide if you want to continue. Overall Rating: 8.35/10.

title: Surprisingly impressive
review: I was always a fan of the old Tobey Maguire Spiderman movies.......until last night. recently released on DVD and SKY Box Office is the latest movie adaptation of the comic book super hero. I was initially dubious as i was just expecting a remake, same story, same clichés just different actors, however I was impressively surprised. Andrew Garfield takes the title role and plays it so well and so much more convincingly than Tobey Maguire, and in a row with Uncle Ben and Aunt May he shows real angst that his parents weren't there to bring him up (great scene). Unlike in the originals, the love interest isn't portrayed like some drippy geek unable to get the girl, it came across much more realistic. The baddie, played by Rhys Ifans, was very good and the CGI creature was done very well. if you are a fan of the super hero genre of films or just want a good movie to watch when there is nothing on then you could do worse than take a look, I was very impressed and with talk of a sequel in the works I think it will prove to be more popular than the originals

title: Boring, and the plot has more holes than a golf course
review:
This movie is sorely disappointing for at least two reasons.

First of all, it is plainly boring; most of the time is spent in pointless, overly dramatic dialogues that possibly would like to explore the emotional side of the characters, but which are so filled up with stereotypes - being a nerd, being a nerd that all of a sudden becomes cool, and being a rebel to your (adoptive) parents that don't understand you - that they quickly become unbearable. It takes you thirty minutes only to get to the point where Peter gets bitten and becomes Spider-man - hey, that could have been easily summarized in the first thirty seconds. Also, when at last you get some action, it is the kind of brawl in the dark side alley that looks like a bland replica of a Michael Jackson video from the 80's - not very exciting.

Secondly, the plot has more holes than a golf course. Every minute or so you stumble upon an unbelievable set of coincidences (your hottest schoolmate and love interest, who is also the most intelligent girl in the class, is also the assistant of your father's best friend and colleague, and also the daughter of the head of the local police - how likely is that, one in a billion?) or into a very apparent lack of coherence (e.g. Peter's hands stick to pieces of paper, but in the following scene they don't stick to the pencil and book he is holding, but in the following scene they stick to the computer's keys so much that they break, but they start to stick only after a minute of ordinary typing). In a scene Peter's uncle tells him that he is absolutely identical to his lost father, but just a few minutes later Peter meets his father's best friend and he won't recognize him. This is the kind of stuff that will break the suspension of disbelief and make the movie unbearable to anyone over 10 years of age.

In the end, for a while we enjoyed laughing at the plot's repeated inconsistencies, but after some time the experience became totally boring; when we realized that just one hour had passed and there was still over one hour to go, we just gave up and saved us the pain.

title: Dawson's got a new Spider trick
review:
So the "Amazing" Spider-man is a product seemingly aimed at the weepy- eyed romantic audience. I think the same flock who herd themselves to see Twilight in their droves would love this version. The same type of people I would assume enjoy a relaxing Sunday morning watching Dawson's Creek, 90210, re-runs of Friends, the O.C. etc.

It had me worried very early on when it was apparent that Andrew Garfield's acting is timid and sheepish, like a teenager painfully trying to impress a group of girls. When he becomes Spider-man and the cocky side of his character comes out, watching Garfield is really uncomfortable, especially when he starts cursing and false-swearing.

And to nail his Dawson alikeness, the director even thought it would be a great idea to have Peter climb up to his love-interest's window each time he visits. Hey - at least he doesn't need a ladder Dawson!

Peter cries a lot, but that's OK because he fights and gets bruises! The girls will love him. But be warned ladies: he doesn't shower after constantly swimming in sewage and that s**t doesn't wash off!

So moving on from Dawson, we've got the villain. He's of the same cut Osborne obviously came from as he loves shouting at the voice in his head and enjoys pursuing madness. Doc Croc comes off as nothing more than a distraction to Peter's love-life and is a poorly visualised CGI blimp who looks strikingly like a Goomba from the 1990's Mario movie.

The truth is though, I wanted him to win. I bet it would have been fun pounding Garfield's wimpy face. And speaking of his face; the director loved it so much he never has it covered. Yes, the new puny Spider-man wants EVERYONE to know his identity, even on one occasion begging a kid to take it off him and try it on. It's true.

No, this isn't a good movie for action fans, especially in the same year as the awesome Dredd is released as well as Avengers. It looks utterly pathetic in comparison and falls short in every category. It's a great movie for aforementioned audience though, which is why I gave it 2-stars. So it's good for something.

Anyone who enjoyed the Toby Maguire version might want to rent this before stumping up the cash for a full purchase. There's no reason to give Sony more money than they deserve.

title: Not Amazing But Good
review:
The Amazing Spider-Man (2012)

*** (out of 4)

This reboot comes just a short amount of time after the third and final film in Sam Raimi's trilogy and features Andrew Garfield taking over the role of Peter Parker. In this film, Parker is trying to discover the secrets of his parents when he's bitten by a spider, which of course turns him into the title character. Spider-Man must then battle The Lizard while also trying to keep the girl of his dreams (Emma Stone). THE AMAZING SPIDER-MAN is certainly far from amazing but I think it was good enough for a summer blockbuster. One could argue if it was too soon to start the franchise up but I'll leave that for someone else. Overall I thought the screenplay was pretty good as it mixed in plenty of drama, laughs and some good action sequences. I'm not sure how many mainstream movie goers would agree with me but I thought the high points was the personal drama. The story of what's going on with Parker was extremely well handled and I thought the screenplay devoted just the right amount of time letting us get to know this character. The Parker here is certainly a lot different than previous movies so I'm glad they really built the character up. The same is true with his relationship with Uncle Ben (Martin Sheen) and even the love story has some good moments to it. The performances are all a major plus as well. Garfield has no problem pulling off both sides of the character and Stone makes for a very good love interest (not to mention the mini skirts on her are great). Denis Leary is terrific as the girl's father who also just happens to be the Captain of the police. Sally Field is strong as Aunt May, although I'd argue that the script doesn't do much for her character. I thought the real standout was Sheen who was simply terrific as Uncle Ben and stole every scene that he was in. Rhys Ifans was okay as the villain but I thought this was the weakest aspect of the film. I must admit that I was bored each time The Lizard was on screen as I didn't find him to be a good villain and the doctor's backstory was also rather boring. I also didn't think there was enough imagination to the action scenes and this is the one spot that was really lacking from previous movies. Still, THE AMAZING SPIDER-MAN is a winner thanks to the screenplay and performances.

title: Film tried to earn brand name but failed. Child film for below 15.
review: Don't know what film wants to prove showing first episode in fourth series ? Not impressive actions scenes. Poor script and direction. They introduced Spiderman in first series with 1 hour. Then came second part in advance. Now in fourth series, they spent 1 hour which already filmed in first series ! Ridiculous. The acting, dialogues proved this is not for even teenager over 15. After Spiderman starts to utilize his strength against crime after an hour of film, SUPERHERO could not prevent himself to identify his girlfriend of being so ! why so hurry ! was intention of the Spiderman to impress girlfriend and others, not primary focus on fight against criminals !! huh... Bent from back-neck, Spiderman himself look like Lizard. Wrong boy chosen for hero, his acting, expressions were never suitable for in-depth student. Ugly Villon character was also unattractive, could have been better. People want villon that really looks deserving and smart enough to make role of hero more impressive. On finishing part, when superhero was told by Stecy's father of getting away from her, why spiderman didn't so practically like Hulk did by going to Brazil without notifying anyone ?! Instead, our superhero stays there to make attractive dialogue and being impressive against his girl friend ! Very cheap script and poor direction. And how his girl-friend came to know about what his father told spiderman at last part to get away from her? Why she was supposed to have that in knowledge ! And the way she told that fact to Spiderman is childish. This was very cheap scripted, directed film under big title utilizing its earlier gains of the series.

title: Another in the long list of recent Hollywood failures
review:
I actually signed up to IMDb after many years of using the service just for this review.

This movie was pretty bad!

The script is all over the place, the acting is very much subpar and to top it all off, you spend around 95% of this 2 hour movie bored to tears.

There is no magic, all the effects in this movie were mastered long ago so the only thing that could have saved it was a decent script and decent acting which were totally lacking.

The only thing that could have lowered the score any further would have been having Uwe Boll involved in the production (I am still not sure he wasn't however I am willing to give the production the benefit of doubt)

title: Spider-boredom!
review:
Not the spidey experience I expected. The 3D effects were nice though inconsistent. The spidey costume, action and web sequences were good. Emma Stone as Gwen Stacy was very cute.

Now the negatives. Andrew Garfield never came close to Tobey Maguire's act as Peter Parker. I very much missed the character Mary Jane, the perennial love interest of Spiderman coz she is not in this movie! The story had many similarities with Spiderman (2002). Which makes it boring as its like a repeat telecast coz the original had far more adorable moments. The villain is just OK. Irfan khan had a blink-and-miss role in the movie.

Overall I felt, marvel should have made part 4 of spider-man instead of rebooting the series. For me it was a good but not so amazing Spiderman!

title: Spiderman 4
review: The worst Spiderman I have seen and could possibly conceive...terrible story and very contradictory to the origin of my favorite superhero. The actors were poor, and chemistry was lacking. Wish I could say something good about the movie, but overall, a huge disappointment and terrible attempt at something that was already excellent! Why would they create a new Spiderman that has a different storyline, from the original books? And why wasn't Stan Lee there to tell them how wrong their interpretation was? Poorly scripted and storyline was ineffective! Back in the day of Spidey, they didn't have the goofy skateboards and lifestyle genre, seems like they thought they could just throw in that trash to attract some of the newbies! Really terrible Spidey, weak looking and not sharp, and same goes for his girl! Mary Jane Watson, where are you? We miss you! Even the editor and police chief sucked! Sorry, but you need to get your original cast back! They were worlds above this poor ensemble of terrible plagiarists! Rate it 1 out of 10!

title: Not for Marvel Fans
review:
I'll keep this brief (or as brief as IMDb will allow). 'The Amazing Spider Man' is to 'Spider Man' what 'Twilight' is to Vampire movies. It seems to be aimed squarely at the Emo market.

The action is poor, the dialogue diabolically bad, and the casting totally inappropriate - Denis Leary as a Police Captain,Rhys Ifans as a Scientist, REALLY?

I love Spider Man. It's SO disappointing to see it turned into a TV Soap-with-superpowers. Worse still, Marc Webb has been signed up for another

If you like teenage angst a la 'One Tree Hill' or 'Dawson's Creek' then you're in for a treat; break out the popcorn and enjoy the movie. But if you like Marvel, Spider Man, or Action movies AVOID!

title: How you don't make a movie - The movie
review:
Without even going into the comic to movie transition this movie is bad. It's so bad in so many parts that i'll recommend whole heartedly to watch it if you want to learn about how NOT to make a film, let me break it for you: How not to tell a story(although the script itself may have been done fine). How not to direct actors. How not to introduce characters. How not to develop characters. How not to make a soundtrack. How not to make camera shooting effects(partly, there was couple of good ones). How to make fights choreography.

It was boring and silly to stupid at many times. It wasn't believable at any part. It was so bad that i think Mr. Webb should feel bad about making it and give copies to schools that teach cinematography and directing so they can teach HOW NOT TO MAKE A MOVIE. that is all.

title: Cringeworthy
review:
Although it has a couple of clever moments, this is not a good film, and basically represents a Hollywood bereft of new ideas. First of all there was no need for a reboot of this character as the other films were very recent.

Second, the film is BORING. It plods along at a very slow pace, going from one clichéd superhero scene to another, with seeming eternal dialogue in between.

I know the main character is a good actor, as I liked him in "Little Red Riding in the Year of Our Lord". But he is given practically no range in this role. There are no other great performances either.

There is very little action, except for the cliché'd, predictable fight at the end, which is basically a typical CGI sequence.

I was a devoted reader of the Spider-Man comic as a kid, and it saddens me to see what he's been turned into. It would have made far too much sense for Gwen Stacy to die in this film, which is what the original character is most notorious for. But naturally they are saving that for another money-making sequel, which is becoming standard procedure.

title: Hated it...
review:
I was one of the ones who actually liked the Toby Maguire spiderman movies in particular spiderman 2 Doctor Octopus was done very very well,those movies had a lot more in particular considering it was a while ago the effects stood out much more than this one, i wasn't a fan of spiderman himself i wasn't a fan of the effects i wasn't a fan of the way the story played out and i especially wasn't a fan of sideman's mask coming off every 10 minutes in full view of everyone.

Hated the fact that i actually watched it all i wish they didn't do a 're-boot' of the series or at least waited till a director with a better vision to direct it, this was just a money maker with no substance at all, worst of all you title the movie 'spider-man' add a trailer and people will pay to see it the ratings of 6/7 i cannot understand i gave it a 2 for one or two scenes that made me laugh when i probably shouldn't have been.

The lizard looked stupid more like effects done in the 90's which for some was ahead of it's time.

title: Horrible and unnecessary film
review:
This film was just horrible. In my opinion its a horrible adaptation and just a bad film in general, as a comic book fan and a movie-goer in general I was disappointed.( caution this review contains spoilers)

What I didn't like: The love between Peter and Gwen was too bland and forced. Throughout the film I kept asking "What does she see in him?, Why does she love him?", there isn't really a reason, its like they are together just because they were in the source material. There was no time for their love to develop, it just happens.

The worst thing about this film is the ending. Where Peter tells Gwens dying father that he promises to stay away from her, after her dying father asks him to, so Gwen can be safe. But, Peter doesn't even go out of his way to tell Gwen about the promise, and he doesn't even comfort her at the funeral,(he isn't even there), So Gwen goes to his front door, on the same day, and breaks up with her!, on the day of her dads funeral, he doesn't even comfort her at all. Then at the very end where Peter is late for class, he promises the teacher that he wont be late again, and the teacher says "dont make promises you can't keep", and Peter whispers to Gwen saying " but those are the best kind", meaning he is planning on breaking Gwens dying fathers promise, and still be with her any way, and Gwen smiles like an idoit. How IRRESPONSIBLE is Peter?, His uncle Ben died cause of his lack of responsibility, and thats the main thing about the character Spider- man. So he is being irresponsible again, Has he learned anything? The ending is insulting to the themes of Spider-man and the fans.

Another thing that sucked was the CGI scenes, it was mostly at night, and it just didn't blend in well at all. The action scenes weren't really all that either, I expected a little bit more.

Things I liked:(although there isn't much) Martin Sheen and Sally Field were probably the best actors in this movie, its too bad Martin Sheen and Sally didn't have much to work with, with this script.

This film also had tbe best Stan Lee cameo, in all the marvel films.

The film left me disappointed and it was hard to actually pick things I liked. As a comic book fan and a movie viewer in general, I found the film unnecessary and horrible.

title: proof, if proof be need be
review:
that the age of super is over.

****SPOILERS+++++

if you thought "super"man dying in superman returns was lame, embarrassing, puke-provoking and just plain stupid, then don't bother with this chunk of crap. it's actually not even a piece, it's more like a dribble stain on the back of a scabby dog's leg.

in typically American fashion, it has reduced the web-wielding wonder to a super hero who needs crane operators to help him save the day. yeah, crane operators. crane operators. crane half-a-brain operators who work five bucks an hour, go home and beat the wife and kids on holidays. those people - sorry if you or any of your relatives are one of them. but anyway, how super is that? not very super at all. in fact, it made the Toby MacGyver films look like they deserved Palme Dors. what is it with American film makers trying to make super heroes not so super after all? they invented them in the first place. why don't they like them any more? actually, i believe it's more a political thing, in line with that idiot Obama's theory that everyone is the same. well i'm sorry, but they're not. you can't fix stupid. it's unfix-able.

this was even worse than Thor, which i thought was one of the worst films ever - doubly so since Kenneth Brannigan directed it. or maybe because of...i'm not sure. but it was immensely crap. no doubt stupid people will love this version of spider-man. but who cares what they think?

title: With Re-boots comes great responsibility.......
review:
Lets get Sam Raimi's trilogy out of the way first. Spider-Man - Awesome, Spider-Man 2 - IMO the perfect superhero movie, Spider-Man 3 - A fitting end to a fantastic series of movies. Tobey Maguire's portrayal of not only Spider-Man, but more importantly, Peter Parker was as if it was lifted straight out of the comic books. His raw emotion, his battle with his inner demons and his fight to keep his own life balanced came across in floods, and that made me believe that this character was real. The supporting cast throughout the 3 movies were top draw, and this just went on to prove that casting the right choices for the right roles, with the right script makes all of the difference.

I wanted The Amazing Spiderman to be up there with these iconic superhero movies. I wanted Marc Webb to take me on a journey that would make me feel as alive and excited as Sam Raimi's vision did. But i'm afraid it fell way short of doing that, and I feel so bad to say it. Whilst I admire Andrew Garfield as an actor, I can't admire his take on Peter Parker/Spiderman. There was too much arrogance in his Spiderman, too cocky when he was called into action. Yes, I admit that Peter Parker did have a certain air of arrogance in the comic books but not to this extent. That was what Spider-Man 3 was all about.....Peter getting way too cocky and paying the price for it. He couldn't seem to convey the weight of responsibility and emotional heartache that his losses and his new gifts were giving him. Tobey looked nerdy, looked like he was a person that could be bullied and he played it perfectly. Andrew Garfield came across as directed.....a good looking skateboarder who had no problems with the girls. Martin Sheen and Sally Field, whilst they perform their roles beautifully, I couldn't help seeing Rosemary Harris and Cliff Robertson as May & Ben Parker. At times I felt the direction in the action sequences was erratic, and badly thought out, whilst the scenes between Gwen and Peter didn't convey to me the same chemistry as Maguire and Dunst did. They were believable. The amount of bad luck and sheer heartache that Maguire delivers in Spider-Man 2 has the power to bring tears to the eyes. His exchanges with Dunst about him not being an empty seat, his struggle to keep Spider-Man out of his life, yet his final understanding that he IS Spider-man, and he must embrace it and sacrifice the things he loves the most to protect them is brilliantly delivered. Amazing Spiderman never brings these qualities over to me. I could bring up Rhys Ifans performance as Dr Connors/Lizard, Emma Stone's Gwen Stacy and many other things but I fail to see the point. Whilst this movie will make a huge amount of money, will be successful, will make stars out of it's two leads, it doesn't bring anything new to the table. It doesn't expand the story, it just tells the same thing we have already seen, but on a below par level.

Maybe the inevitable sequels will give Marc Webb a chance to grapple with the material and get it right, but my main point is that we are still only 5 years down the line since Spider-Man 3. It's just not long enough. Sony should have really given Raimi back all the creative control he had in Spider-Man 1 & 2 and made Spider-Man 4 the movie many of us fans know he could have delivered. I wanted to see Maguire's Peter Parker/Spider-Man come up against more menacing villains, encounter other heartaches, grow a little older and take us on his journey, but that will never happen.

My last point about this movie comes down to the script. James Vanderbilt wrote the script for Zodiac for crying out loud. This is a guy who can write extremely good material. Here though, I really think he fails to grasp the concept. One point that really had my blood boiling was amount of times that Garfield was required to take the mask off. They might just as well of sewn his name on the back of the suit just in case you forgot the face. Isn't this the whole point of a superhero?? Conseal your identity to protect not only your alter ego, but also the people you love? So I go back to my review title...With Re-boots comes great responsibility...and in my opinion, Sony have thrown that responsibility back into the faces of the people who truly wanted something that was going to be special.....it just isn't.

title: A heartfelt comeback from Spiderman
review:
When Sony Pictures announced a Spiderman 4 with Sam Raimi and Tobey Maguire back one thing was sure. It could only be better than Spiderman 3, but it was still with a worried mind I read the news. Sam Raimi dropped out and Tobey quickly went the same way, leaving Sony and Marvel with the obvious choice of rebooting the series. The choice of Marc Webb ((500) Days of Summer) was brave and Andrew Garfield as Spiderman ditto. Having seen it, I can only say one thing: Thank you, Sam Raimi for dropping out!

The film obviously shares quite a few plot lines with the first Spiderman from 2002, but these scenes touched me way more in this version. Quite simply because the characters are more likable, better acted and more human.

This is not like your everyday superhero film. Now I'll admit that I'm not a big Spiderman knower, but I do know that he is supposed to be this very teeny, everyday life kind of superhero. Marc Webb succeeds in bringing this life in a way that Sam Raimi can only dream of! With the same charm, sweetness and wit as (500) Days of Summer he portrays Peter Parker with all the problems of a teenager, but also with all the possibilities that a teen sees in life. Peter Parker is suddenly not just a nerd in a suit. He is a human and for that reason you feel much more connected to him when he is in the suit facing danger.

Andrew Garfield is the new Spiderman and he is leagues ahead of Tobey Maguire. Tobey had some charming moments as Spiderman, but having seen Garfiels portrait, he outclasses him. He is perfect as the teenager who is hopelessly in love, whose parents (uncle/aunt in this case) is on his nerves and who is seeking for a way in life. He produces some touching moments that you rarely see in superhero films. Add to that a comedic talent that secures inch perfect delivery of Spidermans hilarious one-liners. Look out, Ironman - you've just got competition for funniest superhero!

Emma Stone is irresistible as the love interest Gwen Stacy (played by Bryce Dallas Howard in Spiderman 3). Gwen Stacy is in many ways a much more fitting love interest for Peter Parker and Emma Stone is simply perfect! As with Summer in (500) Days of Summer Marc Webb has produced a female lead who it's hard not to fall in love with! The romantic scenes between Garfield and Stome is just as great as the ones between Deschanel and Gordon-Levitt in (500) Days of Summer. Marc Webb is a self-proclaimed romantic and that is why he is able to make sweet romance seem so cool and fitting in this otherwise dark universe.

Rhys Ifans is given the undesirable job of portraying Dr. Connors. Undesirable, because the villainous alter ego of Dr. Connors, 'The Lizard' ends up being a very weak villain character - much like Venom and Sand Man in Spiderman 3. The animation of The Lizard isn't on par with the rest of the effects either and he is not more intimidating than a gremlin. It's sad, because in many ways Ifans gives a performance as great as that of Willam Dafoe in Spiderman (2002).

Those are the major characters, but of the many supporting actors I would like to point out Martin Sheen as Uncle Ben. He had some shoes to fill after Jon Voigts performance in Spiderman. However, I completely prefer Martin Sheens version. He is much more likable, much more parental and way funnier! A very likable character. You should also look out for an awesome cameo performance from Spiderman creator Stan Lee - a very memorable scene!

The story is not amazing, but the script is - the dialogue is very smooth, quick and surprisingly funny. Just as a teen hero should be! The score from James Horner is quite ordinary, though especially one scene with Lizard and Gwen Stacy features some awesome musical notes reminding me of the likes of 'Psycho'.

I have no doubt that this film is too sweet, too charming and too romantic in between the darkness for some, but for me it worked. It succeeded in doing what Christopher Nolan has done with Batman. He has made these heroes recognizable and Marc Webb continues the tradition. Their heroes share our flaws, our feelings and our troubles. I cannot think of anyone better than Andrew Garfield and Emma Stone to do this. Consdering this realistic tone, which obviously makes the film darker, it is a shame that the villain is as cartoonish as The Lizard. For that reason I cannot give a 5/5. But one thing is sure when Webb and Garfield is swinging in to the cinemas again in 2014 I will be there and my expectations will be high!

4/5

title: Why?
review: Why was this made? Let me guess .. to make money? It sure wasn't made for any other reason as everything about it is bad. Spider-man is so un spider-man like it is ridiculous. The plot is weak, the story is not true to the original and it all seems rushed towards a bad remake or Godzilla. The acting is really bad, so much so that I don't know where to begin. In fact this was one of those films I just wanted to end. I almost walked out of the cinema but kept hoping things would improve. They didn't! You know this review wants you to add so many words but I am struggling to find anything else to say about it! Here is my tenth line then. It is rubbish! Don't watch it!

title: Where is the fun?
review: If you want to remake a great movie and soon after the original was released and enjoyed, you are obliged to find something new and interesting to contribute. I didn't think it was possible to ruin Spiderman, already the subject of two excellent and one pretty good flicks but the hodgepodge of writers who brought forth this abortion have proved me wrong. Do all moviegoers everywhere a favor, guys and never write another screenplay, OK? There must be technical manuals that can survive your lack of literary skills and that will pay. Emma Stone was and will be beautiful for a long time but is wasted here. No chemistry between her and Andrew, none! Why there was even a need to cast Sally Field or Martin Sheen, I can't imagine. Less familiar faces would have given these supporting characters more depth. Andrew Garfield is so new and young, I hesitate to dismiss his career outright, but here he is leaping only as high as Ryan Reynolds in "The Green Lantern" and not nearly as high as Toby McGuire as Spiderman! Mostly, though, where is the action and the sense of fun in this god-awful talk fest?

title: Completely inaccurate and a terrible film. Why i urge you to not waste your time and watch something else.
review: This movie is the worst spider man anything ever made. It is Completely inaccurate and a terrible film. And here is Why i urge you to not waste your time and watch something else: )step number one: telling you all the flaws) First of all peter Parker has glasses and when he is bitten by the spider he no longer needs them. but in this film that is not the story. peter doesn't have them from the beginning which is a huge flaw! Also (no offense to Sally Field here, i think she is a wonderful actor and i think Anne Hathaway didn't deserve that Oscar at all) aunt may is not a brunet, I'm sure the only reason they made Sally Field take the job is because they wanted more people to see it. (step 2: criticism) Marc Webb obviously doesn't know the first thing about spider man, and for that i say for shame. if he didn't have the knowledge to make the film why didn't he just not make it? Hopefully the sequel will bomb, and I'm sure the only reason that anyone saw this film is because they were spider man fans, even i fell for Marc Webb's trick and watched it. And that, is why This is a Completely inaccurate and a terrible film. I urge you to not waste your time and watch something else.

title: Possilby the worst movie I saw all year.
review:
We rented it and, even at the low price of Netflix rentals, I felt cheated. I actually felt that I must be watching some low budget take of the Spider Man series. Poor writing, poor acting. Just awful. The movie was lucky that the previous movies in the series were worth watching because it made you want to see this one. Don't waste your money or time on the rental.

I guess I need 10 lines in order for this review to be posted so I guess I'll just ramble on about how bad it was. I'm guessing they dumped a lot of money into the making of the film so they had to go ahead and put it out in order to recoup their money. If I was running a studio and they showed me this movie after it was completed I wouldn't have put it out. But they had to recoup their money and they knew it would make money based solely on the previous movies in the series. Otherwise they probably would have thrown it in the can. Really, really bad.

review:
